Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Abby was an exceptionally small tropical cyclone that had minor effects across Southeast Texas in early August 1964. It formed as a tropical depression and became a tropical storm just 60 mi (95 km) southeast of Galveston, Texas. The storm made landfall near Matagorda, Texas, and subsequently weakened, but its core continued to organize and it developed a closed eyewall. Abby passed over Edna and ultimately degenerated into an area of showers and dissipated.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: "Fatalities: None reported"

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Total damage from the storm was estimated at $750,000 with the majority stemming from crops.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Charley originated in an area of convection associated with a trough of low pressure and later transitioned into a tropical depression, then a tropical storm, and finally a hurricane. It made landfall near Cape Lookout, North Carolina, and caused damage primarily through tidal flooding and downed trees.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: One person drowned in Newfoundland. In Ireland, the rainfall set records for 24-hour totals, including an accumulation of more than 7.8 in (200 mm) which set the record for the greatest daily rainfall total in the country. In the country, the rainfall caused widespread flooding, causing two rivers to exceed their banks. In the Dublin area, 451 buildings were flooded, some up to a depth of 8 ft (2.4 m). In the United Kingdom, the storm flooded rivers and brought down trees and power lines. At least 11 deaths were reported in Ireland and the United Kingdom.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: First passing just south of Ireland on August 25, the storm dropped heavy rainfall and brought strong winds, significantly affecting the coastline where winds of 65 mph (105 km/h) were reported. Rainfall spread across the entire country, peaking at 11.0 in (280 mm) in Kippure mountain. There, a station reported more than 7.8 in (200 mm) in 24 hours, which set the record for the greatest daily rainfall total in the country. Several 24-hour rainfall records were set during the storm, and new six-hour and twelve-hour record totals at Casement Aerodrome were set with 1.63 and 2.61 in (41 and 66 mm), respectively. The rainfall left some areas flooded, particularly in the Dublin area where 451 buildings were inundated, some up to a depth of 8 ft (2.4 m). Preliminarily, it was described as the worst flooding in the history of Dublin. Two small rivers, the Dodder and the Dargle, overflowed their banks due to the rainfall. The River Dargle overflowed in Bray, flooding some areas up to a depth of 5 ft (1.5 m) and forcing about 1,000 people to evacuate; several special-needs people were evacuated by boat. The flood, which originated about one mile north of the town, damaged over 500 houses and brought down several trees. Despite local politicians promising for flood protection after the flood, the town remained vulnerable to such flooding at least 20 years after the storm.

Heavy rainfall flooded rivers, which swept away several people. This prompted officials to deploy boats and helicopters to assist in rescues, although at least three deaths were reported due to drowning in the rivers.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Depression One was the wettest tropical cyclone in Cuba since Hurricane Flora of 1963. The heavy rainfall caused flooding in Camagüey that damaged about 5,700 houses and destroyed 200. Six bridges were destroyed, and a total of 131 roads were unpassable due to the flooding. Officials evacuated 65,000 residents in low-lying areas.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation:
The depression also killed 37 people.
By the day after the depression dissipated, the Cuban government reported nine deaths,[10] although the death toll was later finalized at 37.[6]

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Various provinces including Cienfuegos, Villa Clara, Sancti Spíritus, Camagüey, and Ciego de Ávila
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation:
The heavy rainfall caused flooding in Camagüey that damaged about 5,700 houses and destroyed 200.
The flooding also damaged 15 schools and hospitals, as well as several crop buildings.
Six bridges were destroyed in central and western Cuba, which, in addition to damaged roads and rail lines, severely disrupted the country's transportation infrastructure.
A total of 131 roads were unpassable due to the flooding, and 55 rail lines were damaged.
The flood waters prompted officials to evacuate 65,000 residents in low-lying areas.
A tornado was reported in the city of Camagüey, destroying five Soviet planes and several buildings.
By the day after the depression dissipated, the Cuban government reported nine deaths,[10] although the death toll was later finalized at 37.[6]

Total_Summary_Damage.Total_Damage: Damage to over 1,000 houses, evacuation of about 65,000 residents, and the destruction of six bridges in central and western Cuba. The death toll was 37.
Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The heavy rainfall caused flooding in Camagüey that damaged about 5,700 houses and destroyed 200. The flooding also damaged 15 schools and hospitals, as well as several crop buildings. Six bridges were destroyed in central and western Cuba, which, in addition to damaged roads and rail lines, severely disrupted the country's transportation infrastructure. A total of 131 roads were unpassable due to the flooding, and 55 rail lines were damaged. The flood waters prompted officials to evacuate 65,000 residents in low-lying areas, including using helicopters and amphibious vehicles. A tornado was reported in the city of Camagüey, destroying five Soviet planes and several buildings. By the day after the depression dissipated, the Cuban government reported nine deaths, although the death toll was later finalized at 37. The depression also killed thousands of livestock.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Linda was a severe tropical storm that formed in the South China Sea on October 31, 1997. It intensified into a tropical storm and made landfall in southern Vietnam on November 2 with winds of 65 mph (105 km/h). Once in the Gulf of Thailand, it strengthened further to minimal typhoon status, but weakened to tropical storm strength before crossing the Malay Peninsula into the Bay of Bengal. It restrengthened in the Indian Ocean to typhoon status, but dissipated on November 9 due to wind shear and weakened steering currents. The worst of Linda's impact was in Vietnam, where 3,111 people were killed and damage totaled $385 million. Heavy rainfall caused flooding, which damaged or destroyed about 200,000 houses and left about 383,000 people homeless. Several countries around the world sent relief aid to the affected countries.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Ultimately, the death toll was set at 3,111.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: various provinces, including Cà Mau, Bạc Liêu, Sóc Trăng, and Kiên Giang
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Within three days, the death toll in Vietnam was set at over 150, with thousands missing, many of them fishermen. By the fourth day after the storm, the toll reached 390, and on November 14, eight days after the storm, the death toll reached 464. Ultimately, the death toll was set at 3,111.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The worst of Linda's impact was in Vietnam, where 3,111 people were killed, and damage totaled $385 million (USD). (...) Thousands of schools were damaged, and 130,815 dykes were breached. The rainfall also flooded 1,750 square miles (4,500 km2) of rice paddy crop, about half of which in Cà Mau. A preliminary damage total was estimated at 7.18 trillion dongs (US$385 million).

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The 2011 China floods were a series of floods from June to September 2011 that occurred in central and southern parts of the People's Republic of China. They were caused by heavy rain that inundated portions of 12 provinces, leaving other provinces still suffering a prolonged drought, and resulted in direct economic losses of nearly US$6.5 billion.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Kenneth attained tropical storm status on September 21 and again hurricane status on September 25.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Fatalities: None

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The remnants of Kenneth produced rainfall in the Hawaiian Islands, causing some reports of flash flooding. At Nu‘uanu Pali on Oahu, a gauge recorded a total precipitation of 10.25 inches (260 mm); the gauge also reported 1.6 inches (41 mm) in 15 minutes, as well as 4.11 inches (104 mm) in one hour. Peak rainfall totals on Oahu included reports of up to 12 inches (300 mm). On October 1, rains caused the Kaukonahua Stream to burst its banks and Lake Wilson to overflow behind the Wahiawa Dam. The rainfall produced up to 1 foot (300 mm) of flowing water on Pali Highway, leading to surface runoff which flooded a few homes.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The August 2020 Midwest derecho was a powerful derecho affecting the Midwestern United States on August 10–11, 2020, primarily eastern Nebraska, Iowa, Illinois, Wisconsin, and Indiana. It caused high winds and spawned an outbreak of weak tornadoes. Some areas reported torrential rain and large hail. Damage was moderate to severe across much of the affected area, as sustained wind speeds of 70 miles per hour (110 kilometers per hour; 31 meters per second) were prevalent. The greatest damage occurred in eastern Iowa, and northern Illinois, where multiple tornadoes touched down. The highest winds occurred in Iowa, measured at 126 mph (203 km/h; 56.3 m/s) and highest estimated from post-event damage surveys at 140 mph (225 km/h; 62.6 m/s). Millions across the Midwest were affected by wide-scale utility disruptions, residential and commercial property damage, and severe damage to corn and soybean crops. Cedar Rapids, Iowa, was the most severely damaged, suffering a near-complete blackout that lasted for weeks in some areas, widespread and severe property damage, and an estimated loss of at least half of the city's tree canopy.
Time_with_Annotation: The August 2020 Midwest derecho was a powerful derecho affecting the Midwestern United States on August 10–11, 2020.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: The Iowa Governor's office estimated on August 16 that the storm severely damaged or destroyed over 8,000 homes and caused $23.6 million in damage to public infrastructure in Iowa.
Over 800,000 Com Ed customers lost power in Illinois.
The derecho began as a cluster of scattered thunderstorms that had formed during the previous night over south-central South Dakota.

In eastern Nebraska near Tekamah and Fremont, some of earliest storm damage occurred. Winds reached 67 mph (108 km/h; 30.0 m/s), tree damage was significant, downed limbs blocked some roads. At least one person was injured.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Rick was a tropical storm that made landfall as a Category 2 hurricane along the southwestern coast of Mexico in October 2021. Rick formed as a low pressure system and was quickly upgraded to a tropical depression on October 21. Late on October 22, the storm was designated as a tropical storm and was given the name Rick. A few hours later, on October 23, the storm was upgraded to a hurricane. Rick caused one confirmed fatality in Mexico and caused over $26 million (2021 USD) in damages.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: "One confirmed fatality in Mexico,"

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: "One confirmed fatality in Mexico,"

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Flooding in 2017 affected parts of California in the first half of the year. Northern California saw its wettest winter in almost a century, breaking the record set in 1982–83. The damage was estimated at $1.55 billion, including damage to California roads and highways estimated at more than $1.05 billion. The flooding occurred at the end of one of California's worst droughts on record, and much of the state was unprepared to handle the huge volume of rain and snow.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Flooding in 2017 affected parts of California in the first half of the year. Northern California saw its wettest winter in almost a century, breaking the record set in 1982–83. The same storm systems also flooded parts of western Nevada and southern Oregon. The damage was estimated at $1.55 billion, including damage to California roads and highways estimated at more than $1.05 billion. At least 5 directly died.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation:
The 2015 Southeast Africa floods killed at least 176 people in Malawi, 86 in Mozambique, and at least 46 in Madagascar.
Flooding began on January 14, 2015, and was caused by Cyclone Bansi and Tropical Storm Chedza.
The rainfall in Southeast Africa was recorded as being 150% higher than normal, flooding roughly 63,000 hectares in total.
Through years of research, Africa is said to have shown a complex pattern of rainfall, causing droughts and floods in the same season.
Much of the damage from the 2014-2015 rain season can be attributed to the effects of El Niño.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation:
At least 153 missing. Over 200,000 Malawian people have been displaced by the flood, and about 400,000 African people have been displaced in total.

Paragraph: Two weeks of heavy rainfall killed 176 people and caused US$450 million in damage, or roughly 10% of the country's GDP in Malawi.
'

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The 1944 Great Atlantic hurricane was a destructive and powerful tropical cyclone that swept across a large portion of the United States East Coast in September 1944. New England was most affected, though so were the Outer Banks, Mid-Atlantic states, and the Canadian Maritimes. The storm's ferocity and path drew comparisons to the 1938 Long Island Express, one of the worst storms in New England history.
Time_with_Annotation: The storm eventually became an extratropical cyclone on September 16 and merged with another extratropical system off Greenland.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The storm eventually became an extratropical cyclone, moving northeast, and merged with another extratropical system off Greenland on September 16. The total damage caused by the hurricane was estimated to be $100 million (1944 USD).

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation.text: The 1888 Moradabad Hailstorm was a severe hailstorm that occurred on 30 April 1888 in Moradabad, in the Indian state of Uttar Pradesh. It had the 'greatest recorded loss of life',[1] killing 246 people and 1600 livestock with hailstones as large as 'cricket balls'.[2] The hailstones were reportedly as big as duck eggs and oranges.[3]
Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation.annotation: The event is described as a hailstorm causing extreme loss of life and damage to livestock due to large hailstones.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The New England Flood of May 2006 was a flood event that occurred in New England, especially in New Hampshire and Massachusetts, during the month of May, 2006. It was caused by an unusually strong low pressure system that stalled over the central United States, drawing copious amounts of moisture from the Atlantic Ocean. Most of this moisture was drawn directly over New England, producing continuous heavy rain that led to record flooding near several rivers. (paragraph from the original text)

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: There were at least two fatalities, both in Topsfield, Massachusetts.[2][3]

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: There were at least two fatalities, both in Topsfield, Massachusetts.[2][3]

Total_Summary_Damage.Total_Damage: Damage in New Hampshire was estimated to be well into the tens of millions of dollars.
Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: In addition, at least 550 National Guard troops were deployed in the state.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Ginny was a tropical storm that developed on October 16, 1963, over the Bahamas. It intensified into a hurricane as it moved north and later northwest, maintaining a hybrid-type structure for several days. The storm remained close to the United States coastline for eight days, causing minimal damage with beach erosion, light rainfall, and high waves. Its impact was heaviest in New England, where several buildings were damaged, thousands were left without power, and a snow storm killed two people. Ginny became an extratropical cyclone shortly after striking Nova Scotia at its peak intensity on October 29.
Time_with_Annotation: Ginny made landfall near Yarmouth, Nova Scotia on October 29.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Fatalities: 3 related

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: In northern Maine, the snow killed a mountain climber and a park ranger.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Damage was heaviest in New England, where several buildings were damaged and thousands were left without power. The passage of Ginny resulted in a snow storm across eastern New England, particularly in northern Maine, where it killed two people. In Atlantic Canada, the extratropical storm produced high wind and waves, causing damage to boats and resulting in power outages.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Cyclone Giri was a powerful tropical cyclone in terms of 1-minute sustained wind speed which caused catastrophic damage in parts of Myanmar in late October 2010. The system underwent explosive intensification, reaching its peak intensity with winds of 195 km/h (120 mph 3-minute sustained) on October 22. Cyclone Giri made landfall roughly 50 km (31 mi) northwest of Kyaukpyu, shortly after peaking.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: By November 2, 157 fatalities had been confirmed as a result of Cyclone Giri.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Myebon Township, Pauktaw Township, Minbya Township, Kyaukpyu Township
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Of these fatalities, 138 were in Myebon Township, 11 in Pauktaw Township, 5 in Minbya Township and 3 in Kyaukpyu Township.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: By November 2, 157 fatalities had been confirmed as a result of Cyclone Giri. Of these fatalities, 138 were in Myebon Township, 11 in Pauktaw Township, 5 in Minbya Township and 3 in Kyaukpyu Township. Damage from the storm amounted to Ks.2.34 billion (US$359 million).

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Pali was a tropical storm that formed in the Central Pacific hurricane basin on January 7, 2016. It was the earliest recorded tropical cyclone in the Central Pacific basin and the earliest recorded Central Pacific hurricane. Pali strengthened into a tropical storm on January 8 and reached its peak intensity as a Category 2 hurricane on January 13, with maximum 1-minute sustained winds of 100 mph (155 km/h) and a minimum central pressure of 978 millibars (28.9 inHg). The storm caused severe impacts in Kiribati, including the grounding of a cargo ship and the death of four people, as well as major coastal flooding.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Hurricane Pali had severe impacts in Kiribati, grounding a cargo ship and killing four people.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Additionally, Pali's storm surge combined with the Spring Tide and the El Niño-induced above-average sea level, producing major coastal flooding in Kiribati, which caused significant damage to the island nation's coastal infrastructure, killing four people.

Total_Summary_Damage.Total_Damage: The article does not mention the total economic loss or damage caused by Hurricane Pali.
Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The article states that Hurricane Pali had severe impacts in Kiribati, causing major coastal flooding and killing four people. However, it does not mention the total economic damage in the island nation or any other region.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Severe Tropical Cyclone Hola had significant effects across Vanuatu in March 2018, resulting in the deaths of three people. The system developed into a tropical cyclone on 6 March and caused extensive damage in Vanuatu, damaging or destroying 1,709 structures, ruining crops, and killing three people. The former two experienced negligible effects while New Zealand saw heavy rain and strong winds.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Fatalities: 3 total

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Malampa Province, Ambrym Island, Pentecost Island
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Three people were killed in Vanuatu.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The February 25–27, 2010 North American blizzard was a winter storm and severe weather event that occurred in the Mid-Atlantic and New England regions of the United States. It was a complex combination of multiple systems, including an upper air low from the northern Great Plains states, and a surface low from the Gulf Coast states. The storm dropped heavy snow and brought flooding rains to coastal sections of New England, as well as hurricane-force sustained winds to coastal areas.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation:
New York State police reported two fatalities resulting from the weather.
Heavy snow forced New York State troopers to close 40 miles of Interstate 84 from Newburgh to the Connecticut state line, as well as sections of the Taconic Parkway. New York State transportation officials required vehicles to be equipped with snow chains or 4-wheel drive to travel on passable roadways within the storm's impact area; vehicles lacking chains or 4-wheel drive were stopped or turned back at inspection checkpoints.
In New York City, falling tree branches due to the heavy wet snow and strong winds resulted in one casualty (Elmaz Qyra) in Central Park.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Orlene was a tropical cyclone that caused minor damage to the Pacific coast of Mexico in October 2022. Orlene was the sixteenth named storm, ninth hurricane, and third major hurricane of the 2022 Pacific hurricane season. The storm made landfall just north of the Nayarit and Sinaloa border, with winds of 85 mph (140 km/h).

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: "No victims or significant damage have been reported, according to Nayarit's Secretary of Security, Jorge Rodríguez."

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Orlene left at least MX$12 million (US$600,000) of damage in San Blas.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Cyclone Gabrielle struck the North Island of New Zealand between February 11th and 17th 2023, causing an insurance and reinsurance industry loss of NZ $1.543 billion. The storm brought heavy rainfall and strong winds, with wind gusts of 90-110 km/h and a peak of 141 km/h recorded. The impact was magnified by the fact that the soil was already saturated after previous rains, leading to storm surge and high tides causing damage, with coastal inundation and landslides affecting property and critical infrastructure.
Time_with_Annotation: Cyclone Gabrielle drove heavy rainfall and strong winds to the North Island of New Zealand between February 11th and 17th 2023.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation:
Cyclone Gabrielle drove heavy rainfall and strong winds to the North Island of New Zealand between February 11th and 17th 2023.
Storm surge and high tides also caused damage, with coastal inundation and landslides affecting property and critical infrastructure.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The article does not provide any information on the total number of deaths associated with Cyclone Gabrielle.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Cyclone Gabrielle’s impacts in New Zealand are estimated to have caused an insurance and reinsurance industry loss of NZ $1.543 billion by PERILS AG.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Nalgae (2011) was a powerful tropical cyclone that struck the Philippines and affected Hainan, China. It formed as the 32nd tropical depression of the season on September 26, 2011, and was named Nalgae on September 27 as it intensified into a typhoon. Nalgae reached its peak intensity as a Category 4 typhoon on September 30 while making landfall over Luzon. It weakened into a tropical storm as it entered the South China Sea on October 1 and made landfall over the island of Guandong in China on October 4 as a tropical depression. Nalgae dissipated on October 5 east of Vietnam.
Time_with_Annotation: Dissipated on October 5 east of Vietnam.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: According to the article, 'Fatalities: 18 total'

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Various locations in Isabela province, Cagayan, and Bulacan
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: The article states, 'Nalgae, the second typhoon hit Philippines within one week made landfall along the coast of Dinapigue town in Isabela province. The search and rescue operations for Typhoon Nesat were halted because of the fierce weather brought by Nalgae. The NOLCOM chief Major General Jessie Dellosa said 'Our rescue operations are ongoing with the use of watercraft and rubber boats. We are also continuously coordinating with the local government units to rescue the affected residents in Calumpit and Hagonoy.' The National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council director Benito Ramos said 'thousands of rescue workers were deployed across Luzon and the island's sparsely populated northeast coast was evacuated following the orders from the president Benigno Aquino III.' Nalgae was making a similar path across the saturated Luzon Island as Typhoon Nesat. The wind gusts brought by Nalgae toppled trees and blew away tin roofs of some houses in Isabela's provincial capital of Ilagan. Nalgae continued to worsen the flooding and destruction brought by Nesat. Nalgae was far more stronger than Nesat and plummeted the nation with more winds and rains.' It was later reported that 'at least 8 million people living in the Philippines have experience faced much worse floods than the earlier destruction caused by typhoon Nesat.' The disaster management chief Benito Ramos said 'The fight is not over yet. I hope the (Nesat) floods will wash out to Manila Bay before the (Nalgae) runoff hits the area. If the latter catches up to the former, there won’t be any rooftops left to see above the floodwaters.' The local weather agency announced that the water levels on the tributaries of major central Luzon rivers were still continuing to rise fast and posed a threat to the nearby towns and villages.' The article does not provide information on the death in Mountain Province.
The article states, 'A rockslide in northern Bontoc province caused boulders to roll down a mountainside and smash on a passing van, killing one man.'

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The damage caused by Typhoon Nalgae was estimated to be $250 million (2011 USD).

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The 1991 Perfect Storm was initially an extratropical low that developed off the coast of Atlantic Canada on October 28. It later absorbed Hurricane Grace and evolved into a small unnamed hurricane. The storm caused significant damage along the east coast of the United States and in Atlantic Canada, primarily while it was extratropical. Damage totaled over $200 million (1991 USD) and thirteen people were killed in total.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Despite the storm's severity, it was neither the costliest nor the strongest to affect the northeastern United States. It was weakening as it made its closest approach to land, and the highest tides occurred during the neap tide, which is the time when tide ranges are minimal. The worst of the storm effects stayed offshore. Across seven states, damage totaled over $200 million (1991 USD). Over a three-day period, the storm lashed the northeastern United States with high waves, causing damage to beachfront properties from North Carolina to Maine. The coastal flooding damaged or destroyed hundreds of homes and businesses and closed roads and airports. In addition, high winds left about 38,000 people without power. The total without power was much less than for Hurricane Bob two months prior, and was fairly low due to little rainfall and the general lack of leaves on trees. Overall there were thirteen confirmed deaths, including six on board Andrea Gail, a swordfishing boat.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Massachusetts, Maine, New Jersey, North Carolina, Rhode Island, Virginia, Puerto Rico
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Despite the storm's severity, it was neither the costliest nor the strongest to affect the northeastern United States. It was weakening as it made its closest approach to land, and the highest tides occurred during the neap tide, which is the time when tide ranges are minimal. The worst of the storm effects stayed offshore. Across seven states, damage totaled over $200 million (1991 USD). Over a three-day period, the storm lashed the northeastern United States with high waves, causing damage to beachfront properties from North Carolina to Maine. The coastal flooding damaged or destroyed hundreds of homes and businesses and closed roads and airports. In addition, high winds left about 38,000 people without power. The total without power was much less than for Hurricane Bob two months prior, and was fairly low due to little rainfall and the general lack of leaves on trees. Overall there were thirteen confirmed deaths, including six on board Andrea Gail, a swordfishing boat.

The vessel departed Gloucester, Massachusetts, for the waters off Nova Scotia. After encountering high seas in the middle of the storm, the vessel made its last radio contact late on October 28, about 180 miles (290 km) northeast of Sable Island. Andrea Gail sank while returning to Gloucester, her debris washing ashore over the subsequent weeks. The crew of six was presumed killed after a Coast Guard search was unable to find them.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The Halloween Storm of 1991 left significant damage along the east coast of the United States, primarily in Massachusetts and southern New Jersey. Across seven states, damage totaled over $200 million (1991 USD).

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The 2006–08 Southeastern United States drought was a crippling drought that struck the southeast of the U.S. Several reasons, including an unusually strong Bermuda high pressure and La Niña in the eastern Pacific Ocean were responsible for the drought. 2007 was particularly dry across the region, with rivers and lakes dropping to record-low levels and in some areas. The following summer was scorching hot and dry across the region with record-breaking wildfires. In fact, August 2007 was the warmest August and second-hottest month of any month across the region. Several towns nearly ran out of water during this period.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The article does not provide information on the total number of deaths associated with the '2006-2008 Southeastern United States Drought'.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Jebi, known in the Philippines as Super Typhoon Maymay, was the costliest typhoon in Japan's history in terms of insured losses. Jebi formed from a tropical disturbance south-southwest of Wake Island on August 26 and became the twenty-first named storm of the 2018 Pacific typhoon season on August 27. Amid favorable environmental conditions, Jebi quickly strengthened into a typhoon on August 29 as it headed west and rapidly intensified as it passed the Northern Mariana Islands on August 30. Jebi reached its peak intensity as a Category 5-equivalent typhoon on August 31, with 10-minute sustained winds of 195 km/h (120 mph), 1-minute sustained winds of 285 km/h (180 mph), and a minimum pressure of 915 hPa (mbar; 27.02 inHg).

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Fourteen people were killed in Japan—mostly from falls and flying debris—and 980 were injured.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Fourteen people were killed in Japan—mostly from falls and flying debris—and 980 were injured.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Rafael transitioned into an extratropical cyclone on October 17, a process it completed by 1800 UTC that same day. The system interacted with a cold front and began to lose its tropical characteristics.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: One fatality occurred when a woman in Guadeloupe unsuccessfully attempted to drive her car across a flooded roadway.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: A woman was killed in Matouba, part of Saint-Claude, after attempting to drive her car across a flooded roadway; she was swept away.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: As Rafael passed just to the east of Bermuda as a hurricane, light rainfall was recorded. Gusts over 50 mph (85 km/h) left hundreds of houses without electricity. Large swells from the system caused significant damage to the coastline of Nova Scotia, while many roads were washed away or obscured with debris, but overall, damage was minimal.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Hilary was a Tropical Storm/Cyclone during the 1993 Pacific hurricane season that brought significant rainfall to the Sonoran Desert region of Mexico and the United States in August of that year. The storm made two landfalls in Mexico, one in Baja California Sur on August 25 and one in Sonora the following day.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Fatalities: None

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The 2015 Accra floods resulted from heavy continuous rainfall in Accra, the largest city in Ghana. Other causes include improper planning of settlement, choked gutters, and human factors. The flooding resulted in traffic issues and a halt in commercial activities due to flooded markets and trapped workers. At least 25 people died directly from the flooding, while a petrol station explosion caused by the flooding killed at least 200 more people.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Deaths: At least 275 people died from the 2015 Accra floods and explosion.
Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: "At least 25 people have died from the flooding directly, while a petrol station explosion caused by the flooding killed at least 200 more people."[5][6]

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: "At least 25 people have died from the flooding directly, while a petrol station explosion caused by the flooding killed at least 200 more people."[5][6]

Total_Summary_Damage.Total_Damage: At least 202 people have died and over 60 million GH₵ was released by the government to support victims.
Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: "At least 202 people have died and over 60 million GH₵ was released by the government to support victims."[16][17]

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The San Felipe Hurricane was a tropical cyclone that formed on September 12, 1876, and dissipated on September 19, 1876. It was the second tropical cyclone of the 1876 Atlantic hurricane season and the only one to result in fatalities, with a recorded total of 21. The storm first hit the Leeward Islands and later intensified to a Category 3 hurricane while approaching Puerto Rico. It made landfall on Hispaniola and Cuba, and after weakening to a tropical storm, it re-intensified into a hurricane and struck near Wilmington, North Carolina as a minimal hurricane.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The San Felipe Hurricane was the only tropical cyclone in the season to result in fatalities, according to records of the season.[citation needed] At least two drownings occurred in Onslow County, North Carolina.[5] San Felipe affected Puerto Rico for ten hours, killing nineteen people.[3]

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: San Felipe affected Puerto Rico for ten hours, killing nineteen people.[3]
At least two drownings occurred in Onslow County, North Carolina.[5]

Total_Summary_Damage.Total_Damage: At least 21 fatalities were reported, but the economic damage is not explicitly stated in the article.
Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The article mentions that the San Felipe Hurricane caused significant damage to buildings, uprooted trees, and flooding in Wilmington, North Carolina, but it does not provide a specific monetary value for the economic impact.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Cyclone Trina was identified as a tropical cyclone on November 30, 2001, with gale-force winds present in one quadrant of the storm. The system retained gale-force winds through December 2, causing significant damage on Mangaia, Cook Islands.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: The Cook Islands were placed under a cyclone alert and gale warnings were put in place for the islands of Rarotonga and Mangaia for several days. Due to the slow movement of the storm, heavy rains associated with Trina fell on Mangaia for nearly eight days, resulting in widespread flooding. Parts of the island were inundated with up to 2 m (6.6 ft) of water, destroying nearly 95% of the taro crop and drowning numerous livestock. Several of the islands' main roads were washed out and a few reports of landslides were made.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Due to the severity of damage caused by Trina, its name was retired in May 2002 and replaced with Tino. (...) Following an assessment of the damage, it was determined that US$52,000 was needed to repair losses. (...)

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The 1964 Rameswaram cyclone was identified as a tropical storm/cyclone based on the provided text. The system was first identified as an area of low pressure over the Andaman Sea on December 15, which later consolidated into a depression two days later. The cyclone attained hurricane-force winds around 5°N on December 20 and struck Ceylon near Trincomalee with winds estimated at 240 km/h (150 mph) on December 23.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: At least 1,800 people lost their lives as a result of the cyclone.[5][6][7]

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: About 5000 houses and 700 fishing boats were destroyed in the Jaffna district of Ceylon.[9] At least 1,000 people were killed on the island and many more were left unaccounted for.[10] An unofficial estimate stated that the death toll would likely exceed 2,000.[8]

An estimated 7.6 m (25 ft) storm surge struck the town of Dhanuskodi on the south-eastern edge of the island,[11] submerging the town and overturning the Pamban-Dhanuskodi passenger train killing all 200 passengers on board.[12]
More than 3000 people, many of them tourists and pilgrims, were stranded on the island. The total damage to property was estimated at $150 million.[9]

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Laura was a large but short-lived tropical cyclone that developed over the north-central Atlantic Ocean in late September during the 2008 Atlantic hurricane season. Laura formed out of a large extratropical area of low pressure and slowly developed tropical characteristics throughout the day as it moved over warmer waters. On the afternoon of September 30, Laura had acquired enough tropical characteristics to be designated a tropical storm.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The article does not mention any fatalities or deaths directly related to Tropical Storm Laura (2008).

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: As a tropical cyclone, Laura never approached land, and no damages or fatalities occurred. Since the storm remained over open waters for most of its life, several ships and oil platforms recorded tropical storm-force winds. The highest recorded winds were at an oil platform with the call sign VEP717 at 03:00 UTC on October 1. Winds were recorded up to 47 knots (54 mph; 87 km/h). Despite the lack of impact, the storm's remnants were caught in an upper-level jet stream, and steered towards Europe. There, they contributed to heavy rainfall across portions of Britain on October 5, causing localized accumulation of flood waters. One person had to be rescued from her car after driving into a flooded street. The UK Environment Agency issued 76 flood watches and 21 severe flood warnings as a result of the rainfall.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Cyclone Quimburga was a deadly European windstorm that struck northern and central Europe between 12 and 14 November, 1972. The storm developed over the UK where it caused some localised damage before moving across the North Sea where it underwent explosive cyclogenesis. The storm brought wind gusts of over 35 metres per second (130 km/h) to large areas of the Netherlands, with gusts over 40 m/s (140 km/h) across northern Germany. The greatest damage was reported across the German state of Lower Saxony.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Fatalities: 54[3][4]

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: The storm brought wind gusts of over 35 metres per second (130 km/h) to large areas of the Netherlands, with gusts over 40 m/s (140 km/h) across northern Germany.[6]
The greatest damage was reported across the German state of Lower Saxony, after which it is known in German as the Lower Saxony storm.[6]

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Nock-ten, known in the Philippines as Super Typhoon Nina, was the strongest Christmas Day tropical cyclone worldwide in terms of 1-minute sustained winds. Nock-ten intensified into the thirteenth typhoon of the season on December 23, and soon afterwards, it underwent explosive intensification and became a Category 5-equivalent super typhoon early on December 25. The typhoon made eight landfalls over the Philippines before entering the South China Sea and ultimately dissipating on December 28.
Time_with_Annotation: The JTWC issued its final warning for the system early on December 28, and the tropical depression dissipated in the afternoon.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: According to the article, '13 people were known to have been killed by Nock-ten'.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Various locations including Bato, Catanduanes; Sagñay, Camarines Sur; San Andres, Quezon; Torrijos, Marinduque; Verde Island, Batangas; Tingloy, Batangas; Calatagan, Batangas; and Lubang Island, Occidental Mindoro
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: The article states, 'Nock-ten made eight landfalls in the Philippines. A total of 13 people have been reported dead while total damages have been reported up to ₱6.12 billion (US$123 million)'.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Nina was first classified as a tropical cyclone on November 19, 1987, and intensified into a typhoon on November 22. It attained its peak 10 minute intensity of 165 km/h (105 mph; 90 kn) on November 25 before making landfall in Southern Luzon at the same intensity.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Throughout the Philippines, approximately 114,000 persons were evacuated to shelters, 153,339 were listed homeless, and 1,075 were wounded. Nationwide, 979 people were killed.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: In Matnog, 287 people drowned due to storm surge. In nearby Verla, 61 fatalities occurred, where 98% of the city's buildings were damaged or destroyed and its supply of drinking water was cut off. Throughout the Sorsogon province, 80% of all crops were destroyed and 90% of all homes were either damaged or destroyed, resulting in 400 deaths. In the Albay province, 73 people were killed.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Gene, known in the Philippines as Typhoon Oyang, struck Japan during late September 1990. An area of disturbed weather formed several hundred kilometers south-southeast of Okinawa on September 18. Gradual development occurred as it tracked generally westward, and on September 22, the disturbance developed into a tropical depression. The depression intensified into a tropical storm the next day. Continuing to steadily intensify, Gene turned northwest and became a severe tropical storm on September 25. In the evening, Gene was declared a typhoon, and on September 26, attained its maximum intensity.
Time_with_Annotation: The JMA classified Gene as an extratropical cyclone at noon on October 1, 1990.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Nationwide, six fatalities were reported and twenty others sustained injuries.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: In Miyazaki Prefecture, three people were killed and ten others were wounded.
Two people were killed in Miyazaki Prefecture because of landslides.
A 49-year-old man was killed in a landslide in Shizuoka.

Total_Summary_Damage.Total_Damage: ¥22.9 billion yen or $158 million USD in 1990 values

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The Great Flood of 1771 was a flood event that affected several rivers, including the Tyne, Tees, Wear and Eden, and settlements across Northern England from 16 and 17 November 1771 [1]. Its cause was a sudden thaw of the ice in upper Teesdale, a cloud burst over the Pennines and a continuous period of rain [2].

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Deaths: At least 25 people died in the Great Flood of 1771.
Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: "In total, 25 people died and thirteen or fourteen bridges, including Hexham Bridge, were destroyed on the North, South and main Tyne rivers."

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Newcastle upon Tyne, Styford, Yarm, Durham, Carlisle, and Botcherby Mill
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: "On the River Tyne at Newcastle upon Tyne the middle arch and two of the arches near the Gateshead side collapsed in the early hours of November 17, and Upstream, most of the village of Styford on the north bank was destroyed. On the River Wear in the city of Durham three arches of Elvet Bridge were destroyed, and Prebends Bridge of 1574 was swept away. Further downstream the city's Corn Mill was badly damaged and needed to be rebuilt. To the west, the River Eden also rose and affected Carlisle and Botcherby Mill, flooding the church. as did Solway Moss, flooding local farms and settlements. In total, 25 people died and thirteen or fourteen bridges, including Hexham Bridge, were destroyed on the North, South and main Tyne rivers."

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The Schoolhouse Blizzard was precipitated by the collision of an immense Arctic cold front with warm moisture-laden air from the Gulf of Mexico. Within a few hours, the advancing cold front caused a temperature drop from a few degrees above freezing to −20 °F (−29 °C) [−40 °F (−40 °C) in some places]. This wave of cold was accompanied by high winds and heavy snow.

Total_Summary_Damage.Total_Damage: The article does not provide information on the total economic loss or damage caused by the Schoolhouse Blizzard.
Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The article focuses on the fatalities and areas affected by the blizzard, but it does not provide any information on the total economic loss or damage.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Norman was a tropical cyclone that brought heavy rainfall to southwestern Mexico in October 2006. (Paragraph: Tropical Storm Norman was a weak tropical cyclone that brought heavy rainfall to southwestern Mexico in October 2006.)

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Initial reports indicated two people were missing due to the storm, but it was not later confirmed.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The 1899 San Ciriaco hurricane was a tropical storm/cyclone that formed on August 3, 1899, and lasted until September 12, 1899. It was the longest-lasting Atlantic hurricane on record, with a duration of 4 weeks. The storm reached its peak intensity on August 7, 1899, with winds of 150 mph (240 km/h) and a minimum barometric pressure of 930 mbar (27.46 inHg). The storm caused extensive damage and fatalities in the Leeward Islands, Puerto Rico, Hispaniola, Turks and Caicos Islands, Cuba, Bahamas, East Coast of the United States, and Atlantic Canada. The storm was named after Saint Cyriacus, the Roman Catholic saint whose feast day it occurred on.
Time_with_Annotation: The system merged with a low pressure area offshore France on September 12.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: In the Bahamas, at least 334 deaths occurred. In North Carolina, there were at least 20 fatalities. In Puerto Rico, the number of fatalities ranged from 3,100 to 3,400, with the official estimate being 3,369.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Approximately 250,000 people were left without food and shelter. The number of fatalities ranged from 3,100 to 3,400, with the official estimate being 3,369.
The storm brought catastrophic impact to the Bahamas and at least 334 deaths.
There were at least 20 fatalities in North Carolina.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The 1925 Florida tropical storm was identified as an extratropical cyclone based on its peak winds of 90 mph (140 km/h) and a pressure of 979 mbar (hPa; 28.91 inHg), measured by the USS Patoka. The storm was also large in size and produced gale and storm warnings from Beaufort, North Carolina to Eastport, Maine.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Property damages amounted to $3 million, $1 million of which was in Jacksonville.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: St. Lucia's flood was a storm tide that affected the Netherlands and Northern Germany on 13/14 December 1287 (OS), killing approximately 50,000 to 80,000 people in one of the largest floods in recorded history. A low-pressure system mixed with a high tide caused the North Sea to rise over the seawalls and dikes, causing a large portion of the Netherlands and Northern Germany to be flooded.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: St. Lucia's flood was a storm tide that affected the Netherlands and Northern Germany on 13/14 December 1287 (OS), killing approximately 50,000 to 80,000 people in one of the largest floods in recorded history. A low-pressure system mixed with a high tide caused the North Sea to rise over the seawalls and dikes, causing a large portion of the Netherlands and Northern Germany to be flooded.
In the current district of East-Frisia alone thirty villages disappeared in the North Sea.

The storm is one of two in 1287 sometimes referred to as a 'Great Storm'. Together with a surge in January 1286, they seem to have prompted the decline of one of England's then leading ports, Dunwich in Suffolk.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: A low-pressure system mixed with a high tide caused the North Sea to rise over the seawalls and dikes, causing a large portion of the Netherlands and Northern Germany to be flooded, killing approximately 50,000 to 80,000 people in one of the largest floods in recorded history.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: St. Lucia's flood (Sint-Luciavloed) was a storm tide that affected the Netherlands and Northern Germany on 13/14 December 1287 (OS), St. Lucia Day and the day after, killing approximately 50,000 to 80,000 people in one of the largest floods in recorded history.
Many villages disappeared forever. In the current district of East-Frisia alone thirty villages disappeared in the North Sea.

The storm is one of two in 1287 sometimes referred to as a 'Great Storm'. Together with a surge in January 1286, they seem to have prompted the decline of one of England's then leading ports, Dunwich in Suffolk. In the village of Hickling, Norfolk, where 180 died and the water rose a foot above the high altar in the Priory Church.

Total_Summary_Damage.Total_Damage: Approximately 50,000 to 80,000 people were killed, and the economic impact was significant in the Netherlands and Northern Germany.
Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: This disaster was similar to the North Sea flood of 1953, and it had a major influence on the subsequent history of the Netherlands. As a result of this event, a vast percentage of the country's population was wiped out.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Nesat, known in the Philippines as Typhoon Gorio, was a strong tropical cyclone that impacted Taiwan and Fujian, China. It was the ninth named storm and the second typhoon of the annual typhoon season. After consolidating slowly for several days, Tropical Storm Nesat developed east of the Philippines on July 25. While experiencing favorable environmental conditions such as very warm sea surface temperatures and low wind shear, Nesat strengthened into a typhoon and reached its peak intensity on July 28. (Source: 'Typhoon Nesat (2017)')

Time_with_Annotation.Formation: Dated back to July 21, the system began to consolidate on July 25.
Time_with_Annotation.Peak_Intensity: Reached peak intensity on July 28 with central pressure at 960 hPa (28.35 inHg) and ten-minute maximum sustained winds at 150 km/h (90 mph).
Time_with_Annotation.First_Landfall: Made first landfall over Su'ao, Yilan County in Taiwan at 11:10 UTC.
Time_with_Annotation.Second_Landfall: Made second landfall over Fuqing, Fujian, China at around 22:00 UTC on July 29.
Time_with_Annotation.Dissipation: Issued final warning on Nesat about five hours later.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Fatalities: 3 total

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Damages: $247.58 million (US$4.9 million)
A total of 111 people were injured when the typhoon hit.
Some 70,000 people have been evacuated and dozens of trains and flights suspended in Fuzhou, according to Fujian's water resources department.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Typhoon Nesat caused a total of $282 million (2017 USD) in damages.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The 2016 Maryland flood was a natural disaster in the United States that took place on July 30, 2016. The flooding, which occurred in the Baltimore area, affected low-lying areas of the Patapsco and Jones Falls valleys. On the evening of July 30, a severe thunderstorm moved into the area of Ellicott City where it dumped an estimated 6 inches (15 cm) of rain in two hours. The flash flood that resulted inflicted severe damage to the area primarily on Main Street (Maryland Route 144). Flooding damaged many homes, businesses, sidewalks, and landmarks, including the city's landmark clock. At least two people were confirmed to have died as a result of the floods.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The property damage from the 2016 Maryland flood was reported to be $22.435 million (2016 USD).[2]

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Depression Josie was a tropical system that impacted the Philippine archipelago of Luzon in July 2018, bringing widespread flooding. The storm reached its peak intensity of 1-minute sustained winds of 65 km/h (40 mph).

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Despite being a relatively weak system, Tropical Depression Josie was known for actively enhancing the southwest monsoon that brought widespread flooding over Luzon, Philippines within most of July 2018. In the country, Josie caused ₱4.66 billion (US$87.4 million) of damages, also killing a total of 16 people.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: In the country, Josie caused ₱4.66 billion (US$87.4 million) of damages, also killing a total of 16 people.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Beatriz was a Tropical Storm/Cyclone that killed four people after brushing the western coast of Mexico in June 2011. The system reached hurricane status with winds of 90 mph (150 km/h) but quickly weakened due to its interaction with land.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Fatalities: 4

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Heavy rains from Beatriz triggered significant flooding along the Sabana River in Acapulco, killing four people.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The overall effects of Beatriz were limited and the rains were largely beneficial in mitigating a severe drought.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Marco was a tropical cyclone that developed in the Caribbean Sea during late September 2008. It reached its peak intensity with winds of 65 mph (100 km/h) on October 7, 2008. The storm caused minimal damage due to its small size, but its heavy rains led to flooding up to 10 feet (3.05 m) deep that covered highways and damaged homes.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Fatalities: None reported

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: In June 2013, a mid-day cloudburst caused devastating floods and landslides in Uttarakhand, India, resulting in 6,054 deaths and affecting 4,550 villages. The heavy rainfall received that month was far greater than the usual rainfall, causing major overflow and blocking of rivers. Some parts of Himachal Pradesh, Haryana, Delhi, Uttar Pradesh, Nepal, Sudurpashchim Pradesh, and Karnali Pradesh were also affected. The destruction of bridges and roads left about 300,000 pilgrims and tourists trapped in the valleys leading to three of the four Hindu Chota Char Dham pilgrimage sites. The Indian Air Force, Indian Army, and paramilitary troops evacuated more than 110,000 people from the flood-ravaged area.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: According to figures provided by the Government of Uttarakhand, more than 5,700 people were 'presumed dead.'[3] This total included 934 local residents.[4] The death toll was later placed at 6,054.[1]

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Over 89% of the casualties occurred in Uttarakhand.[3]

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: About 6000 citizens of Nepal were visiting the Indian region, of which 1,000 were rescued as of 22 June 2013.[37]

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: In Himachal Pradesh, floods caused loss of life and property and death toll in the state was 20.[36]

Six-hundred and nine villages, covering a population of 700,000, in 23 districts of Uttar Pradesh were affected by the flood and drought. The number of people who went to Uttarakhand were mostly from Uttar Pradesh.[35]

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Cyclone Gombe was a strong tropical cyclone that affected Mozambique. It became the first storm to make a major landfall in Nampula Province in Mozambique since Cyclone Jokwe in 2008. The storm underwent rapid intensification and reached its peak intensity on 11 March, with maximum 10-minute sustained winds of 165 km/h (105 mph), maximum 1-minute sustained winds of 185 km/h (115 mph), and a minimum central pressure of 960 hPa (28.35 inHg).

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Cyclone Gombe killed 72 people across three countries: 63 in Mozambique, 7 in Malawi, and 2 in Madagascar.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Several districts remained inaccessible for days after Gombe, and heavy winds uprooted trees and ripped roofs off of various public buildings. Electricity and mobile phone services were disrupted, making communication in impact areas difficult. In Zambezia Province, the bridge connecting the administrative posts of Mulela and Nabur to the village of Pebane collapsed, leaving 32,000 people isolated from the posts, and causing scarcities in sanitation, food, and water.
At least 7 people have died in the country; with one in the Mangochi District being a 28-year-old man who was washed away by a flooding river.
At least two people died and one person reported missing.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The January 2016 United States blizzard produced up to 3ft (91cm) of snow in parts of the Mid-Atlantic and Northeastern United States during January 22–24, 2016. A weather system, evolving from a shortwave trough that formed in the Pacific Northwest on January 19, consolidated into a defined low-pressure area on January 21 over Texas. Meteorologists indicated that a resultant storm could produce more than 2ft (61cm) of snow across a wide swath of the Mid-Atlantic region and could 'paralyze the eastern third of the nation', and regarded it as a 'potentially historic blizzard'.[1][2]
Time_with_Annotation: Dissipated: January 29, 2016 (2016-01-29)

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: The January 2016 United States blizzard produced up to 3ft (91cm) of snow in parts of the Mid-Atlantic and Northeastern United States during January 22–24, 2016.
A shortwave trough that formed in the Pacific Northwest on January 19 consolidated into a defined low-pressure area on January 21 over Texas.
The incipient storm system began to intensify as it tracked eastward through the Gulf Coast states, triggering a line of strong to severe thunderstorms and multiple tornado warnings.

At least 55 people were killed in storm-related incidents: 12 in Virginia, 9 in Pennsylvania, 6 each in New Jersey, New York, and North Carolina, 4 in South Carolina, 3 each in Maryland and Washington, D.C., 1 in Arkansas, 1 in Delaware, 1 in Georgia, 1 in Kentucky, 1 in Massachusetts, and 1 in Ohio.
Approximately 103 million people were affected by the storm, with 33 million people placed under blizzard warnings.

The storm was forecast to cross the Atlantic Ocean and affect the British Isles from January 26 to 28. The storm was expected to be less severe, with rain rather than snow; however, the possibility of strong winds and localized flooding was noted.

The storm was forecast to cross the Atlantic Ocean and affect the British Isles from January 26 to 28. Particular concern was raised over areas that suffered from significant flooding during the preceding months.
On January 29, the storm system was absorbed by Windstorm Leone, over Finland.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Severe Tropical Cyclone Orson was the fourth most intense cyclone ever recorded in the Australian region. Forming out of a tropical low on 17 April 1989, Orson gradually intensified as it tracked towards the west. After attaining Category 5 intensity on 20 April, the storm began to track southward and accelerated. The following day, the cyclone reached its peak intensity with winds of 250 km/h (160 mph) (10-minute sustained) and a barometric pressure of 904 hPa (mbar).

The 1933 Trinidad hurricane was a tropical storm that formed on June 24, 1933, and dissipated on July 8, 1933. It caused significant damage in the Leeward Islands, Venezuela, Cuba, and Mexico. The storm killed at least 35 people and caused $7.2 million in damage (1933 USD). The hurricane attained peak winds of 110 mph (180 km/h) and had a lowest pressure of 965 mbar (hPa); 28.50 inHg.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Martha was a tropical storm that made landfall in Panama on November 24, 1969. The storm developed in the southwestern Caribbean Sea on November 21 and quickly intensified into a hurricane with maximum sustained winds of 90 mph (140 km/h). Martha weakened prior to landfall and made landfall as a strong tropical storm. The storm brought significant rains to Panama and Costa Rica, causing flooding and mudslides. Damages reached $30 million (1969 USD) and 5 deaths were reported.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Cyclone Seroja struck Western Australia between 11th and 12th April 2021, coming ashore just south of the town of Kalbarri at 8.00pm local time on the 11th. Cyclone Seroja caused strong winds to impact an area of approximately 800km of the Mid-West Australia region coastline. Wind gusts extended further inland as cyclone Seroja continued a south-south-easterly track into the morning of 12th April and the highest gust speeds were recorded in the town of Kalbarri which reported wind speeds of 170km/h, while other locations in the region experienced gusts above 125km/h. PERILS noted at the time that cyclone Seroja was a comparably ‘dry’ event with moderate rainfall, meaning that most of the damage from came from the storms strong winds.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Winona struck Japan during August 1990. An area of disturbed weather developed within the monsoon trough, located over the East China Sea, on August 4. Despite the presence of strong wind shear, a tropical depression developed later that day. In response to a building subtropical ridge to its southeast, Winona veered north while gradually intensifying. On August 9, Winona peaked in intensity, and while near peak intensity, made landfall in Shizuoka Prefecture early the following morning. Winona transitioned into an extratropical cyclone on August 11.
extra-tropical cyclone (or European windstorm) Thomas (which was also known as Doris in the UK)

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Skip was upgraded into a tropical storm on November 3 and later into a typhoon on November 5. The storm attained its maximum intensity of 145 km/h (90 mph) and a barometric pressure of 950 hPa (mbar); 28.05 inHg on November 6.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: Typhoon Skip made its closest approach to Yap, passing around 100 km (60 mi) to the south. Across the Leyte island, the storm knocked nearly 200,000 people without power and caused $400,000 (1988 USD) in damages. On Cebu island, in San Jose, 80% of the city was under water at the height of the storm. One person was killed in Cebu City. Island-wide, almost 20,000 people were trapped in floodwaters. Along the slope of the Mayon Volcano, landslides triggered by heavy rains forced 2,600 people to be evacuated from the slopes of the volcano. All roads were impassible and thirty-nine people were killed in Tablas Island. Elsewhere, three people drowned on Marinduque island. Two fatalities occurred in Tacloban. Two others were killed in Agusan. Skip triggered widespread flooding on the island of Palawan, especially on the southern part of the remote island. There, seventy-four people were killed and ninety-five were initially listed missing. In a small hamlet of Gilligan on the island of Palawan, the Philippine Red Cross reported that 900 people lost their lives; however, authorities insisted only eight people were killed and that Tropical Storm Tess brought far worse impacts to the region. Nearby, eight casualties occurred in Mindoro. At least 10 small fishing boats went missing off Negros. Moreover, 14 of the 16 towns in Capiz province were flooded, resulting in hundreds of families being evacuated to schools and churches. Greater than 700 people were evacuated from low-lying areas of the Aklan province, where two people perished. In the Iloilo province, on the eastern part of Panay Island, close to 40 villages were under water. Roads around the provincial capital, Iloilo City, were impassible and two major bridges were washed away. Two major bridges were swept away by the typhoon. Throughout Panay Island, eight fatalities were reported, seven of which were drownings while another person was electrocuted by a downed power line. Seventeen homes were demolished, 23 people were buried, and ten bodies were recovered on a landslide in Pasacao in the province of Camarines Sur. Throughout the city, ten people, six of whom were children, were killed. Elsewhere in Camarines Sur, two children died in a tornado. Province-wide, 19 to 27 people perished and at minimum 20 were wounded.

Several areas of disturbed weather developed within the monsoon trough around November 1. One area situated to the south of Guam gradually became better organized, and by late November 3, the system was upgraded into a tropical depression, and a tropical storm later that day.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Tico is a tropical storm that formed in the Pacific Ocean on October 11, 1983. It intensified into a hurricane on October 15 with peak winds of 130 mph (215 km/h). The hurricane made landfall near Mazatlán, Mexico, on October 19 with winds of 125 mph (205 km/h). The storm caused severe flooding and heavy damage in Mexico, sinking nine small ships and killing nine fishermen. In the United States, the remnants of Hurricane Tico caused heavy rains and flooding, resulting in 141 fatalities and $284 million (1983 USD) in damage.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Klaus was a tropical storm that developed from a tropical wave in October 1990. It intensified into a hurricane, but its strongest winds remained to its northeast due to wind shear. The storm caused heavy rainfall and flooding in the Lesser Antilles, particularly on Martinique, where seven casualties occurred and 1,500 people were left homeless. The remnant moisture of Klaus entered the southeastern United States, causing additional flooding and damage.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: In 2016, deadly floods hit Ethiopia, leaving at least 200 people dead and over 200,000 people homeless as seasonal rains come early to the country.[1] The majority of these deaths occurred in the city of Jijiga while elsewhere, heavy downpours of rain were reported with more floods expected in the next few days.[2] The floods are reportedly at higher levels than other flood tragedies than that of previous years.[1]

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: In Ethiopia, the 2016 flood event occurred with heavy Kiremt rains and caused many localized flash floods, landslides, and overflowing of rivers in Lower Omo Valley, Dire Dawa, Amhara, Afar, Somali, Tigray, Gambella, Oromia, and Harari regions.[7]

The drought and floods of the same year affected almost all sectors in Ethiopia, with the loss of crops and livestock and the impact of reduced water resources being significant. Among them, the Tigray, Afar and Somali regions were severely affected, as the drought caused the death of almost 50% of the livestock in the region and affected 24%, 25% and 21% of the population respectively.[14]

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Soudelor, known in the Philippines as Super Typhoon Hanna, was the third most intense tropical cyclone worldwide in 2015 after Hurricane Patricia and Cyclone Pam as well as the strongest tropical cyclone of the 2015 Pacific typhoon season. Soudelor had severe impacts in the Northern Mariana Islands, Taiwan, and eastern China, resulting in 40 confirmed fatalities.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: Typhoon Soudelor passed directly over Saipan on August 2 as an intensifying Category 2 equivalent storm according to the JTWC, causing widespread damage on the island. Post-storm damage surveys determined Soudelor to have been substantially stronger at landfall: a Category 4-equivalent with sustained winds of 215 km/h (134 mph) with gusts in excess of 260 km/h (160 mph). The winds downed numerous trees and power lines, leaving much of the island without power and rendering roads impassible. In some areas, cars were flipped over by the force of the wind. The island's power plant lost part of its roof and was flooded. Damage to the island's electrical infrastructure was tremendous, with 150 power poles and 114 transformers damaged or destroyed. A total of 464 residents sought refuge in public shelters.

PAGASA issued Public Storm Warning Signal#1, the lowest on a five-tier scale, for Batanes and Cagayan provinces, including the Calayan islands, from August 6–8. Signal #2 was raised for Batanes on August 7. The storm's circulation enhanced the southwest monsoon and brought rains to Luzon and portions of the Western Visayas. Overall impacts were minor, with 58,255 people affected; 45,444 of these people sought refuge in public shelters. Agricultural damage in Batanes were at ₱363,000 (US$7,900).

The center of the storm made landfall in eastern Taiwan at 04:40 a.m. local time on August 8. By mid-morning, Soudelor had maximum sustained winds of 173 km/h (107 mph; 93 kn). Northern and mountainous areas of Taiwan saw the strongest winds, with Pengjia Islet reporting sustained winds of 150 km/h (93 mph) and a peak gust of 211 km/h (131 mph). A gust of 230 km/h (143 mph) was reported in Su'ao. These winds caused Taipei 101's tuned mass damper to sway a record 100 cm (39 in). Taiping Mountain in eastern Taiwan's Yilan County saw the heaviest rains from the typhoon, with accumulations peaking at 1,334 mm (52.52 in). At the height of the storm, 4.85 million households lost electricity. This was the largest blackout on record in Taiwan due to a typhoon, surpassing the previous record of 2.79 million after Typhoon Herb in 1996. Water supply to 429,248 homes and land line telephone service to 64,992 homes was cut during the storm. A contaminated Nanshi River suffered a drastic overflow, and soon mixed with the primary water source of the Taipei-Keelung metropolitan area. The river's turbidity reached record levels in just two hours, catching Taipei's Water Department off-guard. The excess water overwhelmed the regional purification system. As a result, the water supply to approximately 5 million households in Taipei was polluted for the next few days. Agricultural damage in Taiwan exceeded NT$3.03 billion (US$94.8 million). The banana crop suffered the greatest impact, with 5,436 hectares (13,430 acres) damaged; losses from the crop reached NT$460.15 million (US$14.3 million). Six windmills of Taipower were destroyed.

Making landfall in Fujian around 10:10 p.m. local time on August 8, the storm brought damaging winds to coastal cities in the region. The strongest gust was 191 km/h (119 mph) in Putian while nearby Fuzhou saw gusts up to 134 km/h (83 mph). Gusts in excess of typhoon force were almost entirely confined to Fujian. Gale-force winds extended into Jiangxi and Zhejiang. Much of East China saw torrential rains from the storm, with accumulations of at least 100 mm (3.9 in) reported in several provinces. Portions of Zhejiang Province saw 24-hour rainfall totals with a return period of 100-120 years. Wencheng County recorded 645 mm (25.4 in) during the same span – the heaviest in 100 years. Country-wide accumulations peaked at 806 mm (31.7 in) within Wenzhou.
The typhoon's remnants brought locally heavy rain to parts of South Korea on August 11, with accumulations reaching 25 to 60 mm (0.98 to 2.4 in).

Prior to striking Taiwan, the circulation of Typhoon Soudelor battered Japan's southern Ryukyu Islands with typhoon-force winds. Sustained winds on Yonaguni island reached 163 km/h (101 mph) with concurrent gusts to 233 km/h (145 mph), the strongest winds recorded in relation to the storm throughout its path. Ishigaki Island saw a peak gust of 198 km/h (123 mph). Farther north at Kadena Air Base on Okinawa Island, gusts reached 84 km/h (52 mph). Heavy rains accompanied these winds, with Yonaguni reporting 451 mm (17.74 in) during the storm's passage. Structural impact was relatively minor, mainly confined to damaged roofs on Yonaguni island. Three people sustained minor injuries in the region. Losses to agriculture, forestry, and fisheries across the Yaeyama District reached ¥360 million (US$2.9 million). A total of 6,748 hectares (16,670 acres) of crops sustained damage. In Miyako-jima, crops sustained significant damage from salt; relatively little rain coupled with strong winds allowed sea spray to travel farther inland than normal. Preliminary estimates placed losses at ¥94.52 million (US$761,000). On August 10, a family of four was swept out to sea near Irabu-jima by residual swells from the typhoon; three drowned while the fourth, an 8-year-old girl, was rescued.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Storm Eunice was an extremely powerful extratropical cyclone with hurricane-force winds.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Two people died as a result of the heavy winds in Ypres, a 79-year-old British man drowned after falling from his boat at the marina, and in Ghent, a man was hit by a broken solar panel and died in a hospital the next day. At least three others were seriously injured. In Menen, an 18-year-old jogger was taken to a hospital in critical condition after being hit by a loose branch. In Temse, a man sustained a major head injury after a metal plate was ripped off a construction site container. In Veurne, a truck driver was hospitalized after their truck was overturned.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: In Ypres, a 79-year-old British man drowned after falling from his boat at the marina. In Ghent, a man was hit by a broken solar panel and died in a hospital the next day. At least three others were seriously injured. In Menen, an 18-year-old jogger was taken to a hospital in critical condition after being hit by a loose branch. In Temse, a man sustained a major head injury after a metal plate was ripped off a construction site container. In Veurne, a truck driver was hospitalized after their truck was overturned.
A fourth person died in Adorp near Groningen, after colliding with a fallen tree in their car.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Pomerania, Mazovia, Greater Poland, Warmia and Masuria
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Four people including two car drivers and two passers-by were killed and nine people injured. The storm brought down thousands of trees, and blocked road and rail transport (mainly in Pomerania, Mazovia, Greater Poland, Warmia and Masuria).

Two people died in Amsterdam after being struck by a falling tree; one of them was a cyclist. A driver in Diemen was struck and killed by a falling tree as well. A third person died in Alton, Hampshire, after colliding with a fallen tree in their car. In Highgate, north London, a woman was killed by a falling tree and a man was killed in Merseyside after being hit by debris reportedly from a tree.
No specific location or number of deaths were mentioned for the Czech Republic, Denmark, France, Germany, Ireland, Lithuania, or Luxembourg.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The storm caused a huge amount of damage in parts of Western, Central and Northern Europe; millions of people were left without power across affected areas, and many homes had sustained damage. The UK was particularly hard hit, with 1.4 million homes left without power at its peak. Several other countries were struck hard by Eunice, with wind damage being mostly the cause of it. Heavy winds damaged parts of buildings, and wind gusts in excess of 120 miles per hour (190 km/h) were recorded. Eunice caused 17 fatalities, and multiple injuries.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Betsy developed from a tropical wave on August 9, 1956, and rapidly intensified into a major hurricane with winds of 120 mph (190 km/h). It made landfall in Guadeloupe, heavily damaging 1000 houses and causing severe crop destruction. The hurricane then struck southeastern Puerto Rico, leaving $40 million in damage and 16 deaths. Betsy was the first hurricane to be observed from the San Juan radar and resulted in the first hurricane warning on the island to be released on television.
