Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The Boundary Waters – Canadian Derecho is one of the farthest north 'progressive' derechos to have ever been recorded. The derecho caused well over $100 million in damage, killed 4 persons and injured 70.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Humberto was a large and powerful tropical cyclone that caused extensive wind damage in Bermuda during September 2019. It was the eighth named storm, third hurricane, and second major hurricane of the 2019 Atlantic hurricane season. Humberto formed on September 13 and strengthened to reach peak intensity as a Category 3 hurricane on September 18. After passing near Bermuda on September 19, the storm encountered stronger wind shear and drier air, transitioning to an extratropical cyclone on September 20.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: "Fatalities: 2 total"

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: "Fatalities: 2 total"

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Gert (1999) was a tropical storm that formed on September 11, 1999, off the coast of Africa. It reached peak winds of 150 mph (240 km/h) on September 16, 1999, and passed east of Bermuda on September 21, 1999. The storm produced hurricane-force winds on the island, leaving 11,000 people without power. Later, it turned northeastward and weakened to tropical storm status before becoming extratropical on September 23, 1999.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: For several days, Gert threatened to strike Bermuda, prompting the evacuation of tourists. Although Gert's center did not make landfall, it passed a short distance east of the island, producing hurricane-force winds that left 11,000 people without power. High waves swept two people out to sea at Acadia National Park in Maine.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Two people were swept out to sea at Acadia National Park in Maine.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Gladys was a tropical storm that developed in the Atlantic Ocean on September 22, 1975. It strengthened into a tropical storm on September 24 and became a hurricane on September 28. The storm reached its peak intensity on October 2, with maximum sustained winds of 140 mph (220 km/h) and a minimum pressure of 939 mbar (27.73 inHg). Gladys passed close to Cape Race, Newfoundland before merging with an extratropical cyclone on October 4.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Fatalities: None

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Fatalities: None

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Intense Tropical Cyclone Berguitta was a strong tropical cyclone that caused flooding in Mauritius and Réunion in January 2018. The system originated from an area of scattered thunderstorms southwest of the Chagos Archipelago on 10 January and became a tropical storm as it turned west on 13 January. Berguitta then rapidly intensified to achieve its peak intensity on 15 January while stalling north of Rodrigues. At the time, the cyclone possessed 10-minute sustained winds of 165 km/h (105 mph), 1-minute sustained winds of 195 km/h (120 mph), and a minimum central pressure of 960 hPa (28.35 inHg).

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Two people were killed on Mauritius: one in a car crash and the other after a fall from a ladder.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Two people were killed on Mauritius: one in a car crash and the other after a fall from a ladder.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Lili was a tropical storm that affected various islands in the Caribbean and the United States. It developed from a tropical disturbance in the Atlantic on September 21 and reached tropical storm strength as it passed through the Windward Islands. The storm caused extensive damage through the Caribbean, particularly to crops and poorly built homes. In the United States, Lili cut off the production of oil within the Gulf of Mexico and caused severe damage in parts of Louisiana. The storm was responsible for severe damage to the barrier islands and marshes in the southern portion of the state. Total damage amounted to $1.16 billion (2002 USD) and killed 15 people during its existence.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: A total of 15 people were killed during Hurricane Lili's existence.[1]

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Two people died in the mudslides these rains triggered, and two more drowned in the flooding around Camp-Perrin.[44]
One person died after the storm, and 20 were hospitalized for carbon monoxide poisoning.[49]

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Severe Tropical Cyclone Alby was first identified on 27 March 1978 as a disorganized area of low pressure. By 30 March, gale-force winds were confirmed and a large ragged eye developed. Alby intensified through 2 April, reaching its peak intensity as a Category 5 cyclone on the Australian cyclone intensity scale with a barometric pressure of 930 hPa (mbar) and peak winds estimated to be 205 km/h (127 mph).

Tropical Storm Kirk was the second lowest-latitude tropical storm on record in the Atlantic basin. It formed as a tropical depression on September 22 and intensified into a tropical storm on September 22 and 26. The storm reached maximum sustained winds of 65 mph (105 km/h) on September 26 before weakening due to westerly wind shear. Kirk made landfall on Saint Lucia with winds of 50 mph (80 km/h) and caused damage in Barbados, Windward Islands, Guadeloupe, and Martinique.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: In Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, rough seas caused coastal flooding and led to the presumed deaths of two fishermen after they ventured out during the storm.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Two fishermen disappeared and were presumed dead after they ignored weather advisories set out from Canouan during the storm.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The 1998 Gujarat cyclone was a catastrophic tropical cyclone that killed at least 1,000 people in India, mainly in the state of Gujarat (Paragraph: The 1998 Gujarat cyclone was a catastrophic tropical cyclone that killed at least 1,000 people in India, mainly in the state of Gujarat).

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: According to the official figures, 1173 people died.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: According to the official figures, 1173 people died.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Iota became the first Category 5 hurricane of the 2020 Atlantic Season on November 16th and struck Nicaragua on the same day.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Deaths: The article does not provide information on the total number of deaths associated with Hurricane Iota.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Total economic losses from hurricane Iota are expected to reach $1.25 billion, again, the majority not being covered by insurance or reinsurance.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: High intensity rainfall since 13 January 2014 caused major flooding across the Interior Division of Sabah including some towns in other divisions such as Kota Kinabalu (Menggatal area), Penampang and Tuaran. Another follow-up heavy rainfall events caused repeated flash flooding in the interior areas in early February.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: High intensity rainfall since 13 January 2014 caused major flooding across the Interior Division of Sabah including some towns in other divisions such as Kota Kinabalu (Menggatal area), Penampang and Tuaran. Another follow-up heavy rainfall events caused repeated flash flooding in the interior areas in early February. The floods affected three districts in the Interior Division such as Beaufort, Keningau and Tenom. As of 15 February, more than 4,000 people had been evacuated to 22 relief centres in Beaufort and Tenom. Continuous rain in Beaufort has worrying officials despite water levels dropping slightly in some parts of the district.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Kelly was a tropical storm that struck the Philippines in June 1981. It formed as a tropical depression east of the Philippines on June 28 and reached tropical storm status on June 30 before hitting the central Philippines. The storm weakened over the islands but re-strengthened over the South China Sea, nearly attaining typhoon status on July 2. The system passed through the southern Hainan Island on July 3 and made landfall in northern Vietnam on July 4 as a tropical storm. Kelly dissipated two days later inland.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: One hundred ninety-two fatalities were reported.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: 120 casualties in the Albay Province
five in Ligao
Late on July 4, Kelly made landfall as a 95 km/h (60 mph) tropical storm 185 km (115 mi) south of Hanoi in Vietnam.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Tropical Storm Kelly caused a total damage of $7.8 million (1981 USD) in the affected regions.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Storm Alex was a powerful early-season extratropical cyclone that caused widespread wind and flooding damage across Europe.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: At least 16 fatalities, with one more person missing.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Departments in the south of France
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: At least 5 people died.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The storm led to 115,000 power outages.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: European extratropical cyclone Herwart
Time_with_Annotation: European windstorm Herwart struck Austria and Germany on 29th October 2017.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The article does not provide information on the total number of deaths associated with 'Herwart'.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The insurance and reinsurance industry loss estimate caused by October 2017’s European extratropical cyclone Herwart has been finalised at EUR 264 million by catastrophe event claims data aggregator PERILS AG.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation:
European windstorm Friederike (David) struck northern Europe in January 2018, causing significant property damage as it tracked across countries including the British Isles, Belgium, the Netherlands and Germany on 17th and 18th January.
PERILS, which has completed its initial assessment of Friederike’s impact on insurance and reinsurance interests, said that the extratropical cyclone windstorm was compact and fast-moving, generating particularly strong winds in the Netherlands and Germany, where a record gust of 203km/h was registered on the Brocken mountain in the state of Saxony-Anhalt.
Storm Friederike’s winds caused severe damage and disruption, bringing the Netherlands and the German states of North Rhine-Westphalia, Hesse, Saxony Anhalt, Thuringia and Saxony to a virtual standstill.
Time_with_Annotation: Windstorm Friederike struck the northern areas of Europe in January 2018, causing significant property damage as it tracked across countries including the British Isles, Belgium, the Netherlands and Germany on 17th and 18th January.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Deaths: eight people in Germany, three in the Netherlands and one in Belgium
Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The initial estimate of the insured property market loss for windstorm Friederike, based on loss data collected from affected insurers by PERILS, has been put at is EUR 1.465 billion. The majority of the insurance industry loss from Friederike occurred in Germany and the Netherlands, PERILS notes. Friederike was responsible for the deaths of eight people in Germany, three in the Netherlands and one in Belgium.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Friederike was responsible for the deaths of eight people in Germany.
Three people died in the Netherlands.
One person died in Belgium.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The estimate for insurance and reinsurance industry losses caused by European windstorm Friederike (David) has been increased by another 3% to EUR 1.675 billion, which suggests that roughly 77% of the economic impact from the windstorm was insured.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Gustav was a tropical storm that formed on August 25, 2008, and made landfall near Cocodrie, Louisiana, on September 1, 2008. It caused significant damage and casualties in Haiti, the Dominican Republic, Jamaica, Cuba, and the United States. Gustav caused at least $8.31 billion (2008 USD) in damages.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: Hurricane Gustav made landfall in Haiti at approximately 1 pm EDT on August 26, about 10 miles (16 km) west of the city of Jacmel. While inland, Gustav's rains triggered a landslide in the community of Benet which killed one person. Two more were killed in southwestern Haiti when their house collapsed. Another two deaths were caused by an explosion inside a house, thought to be possibly related to Hurricane Gustav. The southern town of Jacmel, where the hurricane made landfall, was bisected by floodwaters. According to Haiti's National Director of Civil Protection, 77 people died as a result of the hurricane. Some 2,100 houses were destroyed and another 8,150 damaged, causing an estimated 7,200 people to live in temporary shelters, including churches, community centers and schools.

In Jamaica, 15 deaths were reported after Gustav swept through the area as a tropical storm. Flash flooding was also reported on the island as a result of Gustav's heavy rains. The banana sector in the parishes of St. Thomas, St. Mary and Portland suffered significant damage. The Hope River Bridge linking the capital Kingston with the eastern reaches of the city including Harbour View and St. Thomas collapsed and the Georgia bridge in Portland was destroyed. Jamaica's government ministry initially estimated US$41.8 million in damage to the road infrastructure in the country. Total damage in Jamaica was estimated at $210 million.

On Saturday August 30, 2008, Gustav made landfall on mainland Cuba near the community of Los Palacios in Pinar del Río—a region that produces much of the tobacco used to make the nation's famed cigars. In Los Palacios some 7,000 homes were roofless and many with their walls collapsed. The rice and banana farms sustained much damage. At least 300,000 people were evacuated from Gustav's path as 155 mph (249 km/h) winds toppled telephone poles and fruit trees, shattered windows and tore off the tin roofs of homes. Cuban authorities declared that Gustav is the worst hurricane to hit the country in 50 years. Authorities called the storm damage the worst since 1956. The 211 mph (340 km/h) wind gusts registered in the city of Paso Real de San Diego were the highest in Cuba's history, according to the provincial newspaper, the Guerrillero. Winds were so strong that the weather station instruments broke. Gustav is considered Cuba's worst hurricane in 45 years, the last hurricane that was worse than Gustav for Cuba was Hurricane Flora in 1963, which was the deadliest Cuban storm since the 1932 Cuba Hurricane.

In the state of Louisiana, 34 parishes were declared as disaster areas. Hurricane Gustav reached the Louisiana coast on the morning of September 1, making landfall near Cocodrie, Louisiana. Forty-eight deaths in the state of Louisiana were blamed on Hurricane Gustav. Five were due to falling trees, two due to a tornado and the rest were indirect deaths. Around 1.5 million people were without power in Louisiana on September 1. The city of New Orleans had the official reopening date on Thursday (Sept. 4), after crews had restored most electric power and other services. Damage included numerous trees down in various locations, such as around some Marriott hotels, and large tree limbs were broken from oak trees along St. Charles Avenue. Millions of smaller branches were scattered throughout neighborhoods, blown by the strong winds. Area hotels planned to reopen the week of September 8, some by Saturday, September 6. The Associated Press reported on the floodwall along the Industrial Canal, which connects Lake Pontchartrain to the Mississippi River, and is susceptible to surges via the Gulf Outlet. High water splashed over the floodwalls onto new splash guards, but the walls were not breached. Minor street flooding began in the upper Ninth Ward of New Orleans. In Baton Rouge, Louisiana, it was considered to be the worst storm to hit the area since Hurricane Betsy in 1965. An elderly couple was killed when a tree fell on the house they were temporarily staying in and 85% of the area lost power.

Damage and significant power outages were reported as far north as northern Louisiana, in the Interstate 20 corridor. Highest rainfall totals received thus far across the state include 11.25 inches (286 mm) at Hamburg, making Gustav the third wettest tropical cyclone to affect the state since 1972.

Because of Gustav's slow motion across northwest Louisiana and Arkansas on September 4 and 5, significant rainfall accumulation was seen statewide. The maximum amount in Arkansas was at Hamburg, where 11.25 inches (286 mm) had fallen.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: In total, an estimated 153 deaths had been attributed to Gustav in the U.S. and Caribbean.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: According to Haiti's National Director of Civil Protection, 77 people died as a result of the hurricane.

At least 300,000 people were evacuated from Gustav's path as 155 mph winds toppled telephone poles and fruit trees, shattered windows and tore off the tin roofs of homes. Cuban authorities declared that Gustav is the worst hurricane to hit the country in 50 years.
Forty-eight deaths in the state of Louisiana were blamed on Hurricane Gustav. Five were due to falling trees, two due to a tornado and the rest were indirect deaths.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Mamie was a tropical storm that formed in mid-August 1985 near the Philippines. It attained typhoon intensity on August 17 and reached its peak intensity of 120 km/h (75 mph) that day. The storm made landfall near Shanghai on August 18 and caused widespread flooding, forcing factories to close, toppling trees, and damaging homes. Nearly 1 million people were directly affected by the typhoon, and losses totaled $172 million.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: "Losses totaled $172 million. Overall, 17 people perished and 165 were injured." (Paragraph 3)

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Various locations, including Shanghai, Yantai, and Dairen
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: "Typhoon Mamie killed more than 120,000 animals and sank more than 200 boats in Yantai. In all, 17 people perished and 165 were injured." (Paragraph 4)

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Maria was a Category 1 hurricane that made landfall on the island of Newfoundland during September 2011. It originated from a tropical wave over the central Atlantic on September 6 and made landfall on September 16.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: "There were no deaths reported in association with Maria,"

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Kyle, known in the Philippines as Typhoon Luring, was a tropical storm/cyclone that formed from a monsoon depression near Palau and impacted the Caroline Islands, Palau, Yap, Philippines, Vietnam, Cambodia, and Thailand during the 1993 Pacific typhoon season. The system strengthened to a tropical storm on November 19 and made landfall in the Philippines as a minimal storm, causing minor damages and one fatality. After crossing the country, it intensified into a typhoon in the South China Sea and made another landfall in Vietnam, causing significant damages and over 100 fatalities.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Officials in Vietnam reported 106 deaths, 59 missing, and 476 injuries due to the typhoon.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Officials in Vietnam reported 106 deaths, 59 missing, and 476 injuries due to the typhoon.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The typhoon caused over $1.5 million (1993 USD) in total, mainly from washed-out crops and farmlands in the country.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Edouard was a tropical storm that reached winds of 145 mph (233 km/h) during its path. It remained a major hurricane for eight days, an unusually long amount of time. The storm formed near the coast of Africa in the middle of August and moved westward then curved northward, persisting until early September when it became extratropical to the southeast of New England.

Hurricane Dot was a powerful tropical storm that affected Hawaii in August 1959. It was first identified as a strong tropical storm southeast of Hawaiʻi on August 1. The storm quickly intensified, reaching hurricane intensity six hours after naming. At its peak, Hurricane Dot had maximum sustained winds of 150 mph (240 km/h) and a minimum barometric pressure of 952 mbar (hPa; 28.11 inHg). The storm made landfall on Kauai as a minimal hurricane before dissipating west of the Hawaiian Islands on August 8.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Fatalities: 2 indirect

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Two indirect deaths occurred in Lanai.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Hurricane Dot was the costliest tropical cyclone in Hawaiian history, with damage totaling US$6 million (1959 USD).

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Danielle was a strong tropical storm that made landfall on Virginia in the 1992 Atlantic hurricane season. It formed out of a stationary trough of low pressure on September 18 near the coast of North Carolina and reached tropical storm status just six hours after forming. Danielle looped to the west due to a change in steering currents and reached a peak of 65 mph (105 km/h) winds before weakening and hitting the Delmarva Peninsula. The storm quickly dissipated over land.

Cyclone Anne was a European windstorm which caused €75 million in damage across western Europe in early January 2014, following days later by Cyclone Christina. The low pressure system was named Anne by the Free University of Berlin on 1 January. Some media referred to Anne as the 'Moon Storm'. The Anne storm was deepened by the powerful jet stream, capable of adding over half a meter to sea levels, and coincided with high spring tides and high discharge levels in rivers and estuaries. The long fetch of winds over the western Atlantic pushed water against the coasts and helped to develop significant wave heights.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The article does not provide any information on the total number of deaths associated with Cyclone Anne (2014).

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation:
At 00:00 UTC on October 23, both the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) and the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) started tracking the system, which had developed into a tropical storm.
At 06:00 UTC on October 26, the JTWC designated Warren a typhoon while increasing the intensity of Warren to 120 km/h (75 mph), its maximum intensity.
The JMA estimates that Warren peaked in intensity, with winds of 115 km/h (70 mph) and a minimum barometric pressure of 980 hPa (29 inHg).
Later that day, Warren stalled out for the next 12 hours, only to drift east-northeast in response to the inflow to Typhoon Vanessa and a trough to its north.
On October 28, after re-entering PASAGA's warning responsibility, Warren slowed and made a cyclonic turn back to the east-northeast as the trough moved to the east of Warren and a subtropical ridge became center to the north of the cyclone.
By October 29, Warren began to expand in size in response to a monsoonal surge of moisture into the South China Sea. This also caused the storm to inherit cooler, drier air, which prompted weakening while also recurving towards the northeast.
At 00:00 UTC on October 29, the JTWC downgraded Warren into a tropical storm, though the JMA would not follow suit until 36 hours later.
Despite this, the storm's center remained well-defined for an additional 24 hours.
The remnants of the storm later crossed the coast of Vietnam, with winds of 55 to 65 km/h (35 to 40 mph).
Late on November 1, the circulation had become less defined and increasingly difficult to locate, and the JTWC estimated that Warren dissipated the next day.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: An area of convection was first observed on October 17 in the Philippine Sea. After killing 17 while crossing the archipelago, the system developed into a tropical storm on October 23. Warren moved north and later north-northwest but late on October 24, the storm began to meander in the South China Sea. On October 26, Warren drifted west while attaining peak strength. Two days later, Warren turned back to the east-northeast and away from the Philippines. A weakened trend began on October 29 as the storm entertained cooler, drier air. Despite this, the storm's center of circulation remained well-defined until Warren moved ashore in Vietnam on November 1. Warren dissipated the next day.

The remnants of the storm later crossed the coast of Vietnam, with winds of 55 to 65 km/h (35 to 40 mph). Late on November 1, the circulation had become less defined and increasingly difficult to locate, and the JTWC estimated that Warren dissipated the next day.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Nearby, another cargo container ship, the Lorcon 8, sank but all 19 crewmen were rescued. Across the island chain, 73 people died, 25 due to landslides, while 18 others were injured.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Across the island chain, 73 people died, 25 due to landslides, while 18 others were injured.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: European windstorm Elon-Felix, also known as Dagmar-Egon in Denmark and Sweden, and as Nina in Norway, is categorized as an Extratropical Storm/Cyclone event. The two low-pressure systems that make up Elon-Felix occurred so close together that the losses are difficult to separate, and PERILS reports on them as a single European windstorm event. Elon-Felix affected Western and Northern Europe from 8th to 11th January 2015.
Time_with_Annotation: Elon-Felix affected Western and Northern Europe from 8th to 11th January 2015.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Deaths: The article does not provide information on the total number of deaths associated with 'Elon-Felix|Dagmar-Elon|Nina'.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: PERILS’ initial estimate of the insured industry-wide property market loss for Elon-Felix is €328m.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: In mid-January 2022, the Southern Cone experienced a severe heat wave, making it the hottest place on earth with temperatures exceeding those of the Middle East. This extreme weather event was associated with the Atlantic anticyclone, a particularly intense La Niña phenomenon in the Pacific Ocean, and the regional effects of climate change.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: On January 12 in Buenos Aires, there were 3 heat-related deaths.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: On January 12 the city saw 3 heat-related deaths.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Bob was a tropical cyclone that formed in the Gulf of Mexico in July 1979. The storm brought moderate damage to portions of the United States Gulf Coast and areas farther inland. Bob was the first Atlantic tropical cyclone to be officially designated using a masculine name after the discontinuation of Joint Army/Navy Phonetic Alphabet names. The storm produced a moderate storm surge, damaging some coastal installments and causing coastal inundation. Strong winds were also associated with Bob's landfall, though no stations observed winds of hurricane force. The winds downed trees and blew out windows, in addition to causing widespread power outages. Heavy rainfall was also reported in some locations, peaking at 7.16 in (182 mm) in Louisiana.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Hurricane Bob caused approximately $20 million in damage.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The February flood of 1825 was a devastating flood that occurred from 3 to 5 February 1825 on the North Sea coast in which about 800 people were drowned. Particularly affected were the North Sea coast of Jutland, Slesvig and Germany, where the sand spit Agger Tange was broken through, and the Limfjord got its western opening to the sea. In North Frisia, the unprotected islets, known as Halligen, were hit, and many dykes had already been damaged in November the year before by a severe storm surge. The island of Pellworm was completely flooded. In East Frisia, the town of Emden was particularly hard hit, but the raised levees in the East Frisian area saved many lives. In the Netherlands, the February flood was the worst natural disaster of the 19th century, with most of the dead and the worst damage occurring in Groningen, Friesland and Overijssel.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The February flood of 1825, also known in Germany as the Great Hallig Flood (Große Halligflut), was a devastating flood that occurred from 3 to 5 February 1825 on the North Sea coast in which about 800 people were drowned.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: North Sea coast of Jutland, Slesvig

The sand spit Agger Tange was broken through, and the Limfjord got its western opening to the sea. Henceforth, North Jutland has been an island. In North Frisia, the unprotected islets, known as Halligen, were hit. Many dykes had already been damaged in November the year before by a severe storm surge. The island of Pellworm was completely flooded.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Sam was a powerful and long-lived Cape Verde hurricane that threatened Bermuda, lasting from late September through early October. It was the fifth longest-lasting intense Atlantic hurricane, as measured by accumulated cyclone energy, since reliable records began in 1966. Sam became a Category 4 hurricane with maximum sustained winds of 155 mph (249 km/h) and a minimum central pressure of 927 mbar (27.4 inHg). The storm turned towards the northwest early on September 27, and began to weaken due to an eyewall replacement cycle. It finally dropped below major hurricane status on October 3. Sam completed its transition into an extratropical cyclone on October 5.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The article states 'Fatalities: None'.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: There were no injuries or fatalities from Hurricane Sam. Damage was minimal.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Isa was a tropical storm that developed in the Pacific Ocean in April 1997. It caused moderate winds and rainfall on Pohnpei and Guam, resulting in damage worth over $1 million. The storm weakened and dissipated as it moved northeast.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: No deaths were reported.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The Main_Event identified is 'Drought' based on the text which states 'A drought hit the United States in the 1930s, and the lack of rainfall, snowfall, and moisture in the air dried out the topsoil in most of the country's farming regions.' The dust storms were a consequence of this drought.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The destruction caused by the dust storms, and especially by the storm on Black Sunday, killed multiple people [citation needed] and caused hundreds of thousands of people to relocate.[6]

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: The storm hit Beaver, Oklahoma around 4 p.m., Boise City around 5:15, and Amarillo, Texas, at 7:20. The conditions were the most severe in the Oklahoma and Texas panhandles, but the storm's effects were also felt in surrounding areas. Drought, erosion, bare soil, and winds caused the dust to fly freely and at high speeds.[1]

Total_Summary_Damage.Total_Damage: It is estimated that 300 thousand tons of topsoil were displaced from the prairie area.
Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: It is estimated that 300 thousand tons of topsoil were displaced from the prairie area.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Leslie (2018) was an extratropical cyclone that formed from a subtropical storm and later transitioned back into a hurricane. The storm was responsible for significant damage and fatalities in Portugal, Spain, and France.
Time_with_Annotation:
Formed: 23 September 2018
Extratropical: 13 October 2018
Dissipated: 16 October 2018

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: In November 2018, Aon estimated that Leslie's damage total exceeded €424 million (US$500 million).[nb 1] Hurricane Leslie prompted the issuance of tropical storm watches and warnings for Madeira Island. Leslie brought wind gusts up to 190 km/h (120 mph) to Portugal, felling thousands of trees, causing the collapse of hundreds of structures, and damaging hundreds of buildings, signs, and pieces of equipment. Over 300,000 citizens were left without power. Damage across the country was estimated to be €120 million (US$145 million). City, municipal, and the national government provided funds to repair damage to buildings as well as the local forests, and also launch cleanup efforts. Leslie brought strong winds and torrential rainfall to Spain, most notably the Catalonia region, causing a river to spill its banks, nearly four dozen landslides to occur, and damaging several structures and vehicles. The storm disrupted transportation and caused 14,000 power outages throughout the country. Leslie and a cold front, the latter of which was almost stationary, combined to cause record-breaking flooding in the Aude, France. The flooding in the department was considered to be the worst since 1891. Floodwaters damaged buildings, roads, and vehicles throughout several towns and cities, causing €220 million (US$254 million) in damage. Nearly 1,000 people were evacuated when a dam overflowed in Pezens Municipality, and over 8,000 people lost power nationwide.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Nearly 1,000 people were evacuated when a dam overflowed in Pezens Municipality, and over 8,000 people lost power nationwide.
At least 75 additional people were injured in the department.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: European windstorm Burglind, also known as Eleanor in the UK and Ireland, caused significant damage and insured losses across Austria, Belgium, France, Germany, Ireland, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom between 2nd and 3rd January 2018.

Time_with_Annotation.Source: Extratropical cyclone Burglind, named Eleanor in the UK and Ireland, caused significant damage and insured losses across Austria, Belgium, France, Germany, Ireland, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom between 2nd and 3rd January 2018.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The article does not provide any information on the total number of deaths associated with Burglind|Eleanor.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The estimate of insurance and reinsurance industry losses caused by European windstorm Burglind, also known as Eleanor in the UK, has risen by another 6% to EUR 840 million (PERILS AG).

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Matthew was an extremely powerful Atlantic hurricane which caused catastrophic damage and a humanitarian crisis in Haiti, as well as widespread devastation in the southeastern United States. The deadliest Atlantic hurricane since Hurricane Stan in 2005, and the first Category 5 Atlantic hurricane since Felix in 2007, Matthew was the thirteenth named storm, fifth hurricane and second major hurricane of the 2016 Atlantic hurricane season. It caused extensive damage to landmasses in the Greater Antilles, and severe damage in several islands of the Bahamas which were still recovering from Joaquin, which had pounded the archipelago nearly a year earlier. Matthew also approached the southeastern United States, but stayed just offshore, paralleling the Florida coastline.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Deaths: The article mentions a total of 603 deaths associated with Hurricane Matthew.
Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: "Fatalities: 603 total"

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: The article mentions that 546 people died in Haiti.

Evacuations continued through the hurricane's landfall with the total number of people in shelters reaching 9,280 by 2:00 a.m. local time on October 4.", "Provisional President of Haiti Jocelerme Privert urged those living along the coast and in poorly constructed homes to evacuate and comply with authorities."
"Officially, 546 deaths were attributed to the storm in Haiti, however local governments believed the death toll to be over 1,000; this value may have been overestimated."

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Charley was the third named storm of the 1998 Atlantic hurricane season. The storm originated with a tropical wave that moved off the West African coast on August 9 and developed into a tropical storm later that day. Charley made landfall near Port Aransas, Texas, on August 23, and dissipated near Del Rio, Texas, on August 24.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Twenty people died, all from drowning.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Seven people died in Ciudad Acuña while they were trying to cross a flooded gully.
Four people, including two toddlers, died when their truck was swept away by floodwaters and nine more drowned in flooding along the San Felipe Creek. Thirteen people died in Texas, all drownings.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Twenty people died, all from drowning, and the storm caused $50 million (1998 USD; US$64 million in 2007) in damage.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Nari (pronounced [na.ɾi]) was a strong and deadly tropical cyclone that made landfall in the Philippines and Vietnam. The storm was the 41st depression and the 8th typhoon in the 2013 typhoon season. Nari made landfall on October 14, 2013 as a moderate category 1 typhoon.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Sinlaku was a weak tropical cyclone that impacted Vietnam, Thailand and Laos in August 2020. The storm began as a tropical depression in the South China Sea and strengthened into a tropical storm the following day. Sinlaku made landfall in Vietnam as a broad but weak tropical storm, leading to its dissipation on August 3. The storm brought heavy monsoonal rains to much of Southeast Asia, causing damages and fatalities in Vietnam, Thailand, and Laos.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Two people were killed in Vietnam, and two people were killed in Thailand.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Hoa Binh and Quang Ninh provinces
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Two people were killed in Vietnam.
Two people were killed in Thailand.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The January 2013 Northwest Pacific cyclone was a powerful extratropical cyclone which caused heavy rainfall and a severe blizzard in Japan in January 2013. (from the text) The storm quickly intensified in the southern sea off Japan on January 14, and reached its peak intensity east of Japan on January 15. (from the text) The system then weakened, crossed the Kamchatka Peninsula late on January 18, and dissipated east of Hokkaido on January 21. (from the text)

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation:
The powerful extratropical cyclone which passed over the sea south of Japan caused heavy rainfall and snowfall in the country on January 14. In Tokyo, the blizzard dumped 8 cm (3.1 in) of snow in nine hours. It also left 13 cm (5.1 in) of snow in the neighboring city Yokohama and 30 cm (12 in) of snow in mountainous areas around Tokyo.
About 1600 injuries were recorded in Japan.
A large chunk of frozen snow fell from the Tokyo Skytree and crashed into the roof of a house below, leaving a 30 cm (12 in) hole.
As January 14 was also Coming of Age Day in 2013, many young Japanese people who were celebrating their 20th year had to walk through heavy snowfall to attend Coming of Age Day ceremonies.
The January 2013 Northwest Pacific cyclone formed northeast of Taiwan on January 13.

Late on January 18, the center crossed the southernmost point of the Kamchatka Peninsula and arrived at the Sea of Okhotsk, when the atmospheric pressure was 986 hPa (29.1 inHg).
The system finally dissipated to the far east of Hokkaido on January 21.

Total_Summary_Damage.Total_Damage: The article does not mention the total economic loss or damage caused by the 'January 2013 Northwest Pacific cyclone'.
Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The article mentions 'About 1600 injuries were recorded in Japan.' and 'A large chunk of frozen snow fell from the Tokyo Skytree and crashed into the roof of a house below, leaving a 30 cm (12 in) hole.' but it does not provide any information on the economic loss or damage caused by these incidents.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Very Severe Cyclonic Storm Ockhi was a strong tropical cyclone that devastated parts of Sri Lanka and India in 2017, and was the most intense tropical cyclone in the Arabian Sea since Cyclone Megh in 2015. Ockhi intensified into a cyclonic storm on November 30 due to high atmospheric moisture and warmer oceanic surface temperature between Sri Lanka and Kanyakumari in mainland India.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Though it rapidly weakened during its final stages over the Arabian Sea, it caused at least 245 fatalities, including 218 in India[6] and 27 in Sri Lanka[7].

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: The cyclone claimed five lives in the Kanyakumari District of Tamil Nadu on November 30, caused by falling trees.[54]
The cyclone hit the Lakshadweep islands, suffering more than Rs 500 crore (US$77.5 million) loss.[38]

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Matara, and the general Matara District
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: The system produced heavy rainfall and gale-force winds in Sri Lanka, initially affecting the southern coastline, with Matara, and the general Matara District in particular, experiencing wind speeds of 70–80 km/h (40–50 mph) and bearing the brunt of the cyclone.[40] Falling trees and damage to power transmission lines resulted in power outages in affected areas, with Matara, Galle and Ambalangoda among the worst affected.[40]

As of December 3, 2017, the cyclone had caused 26 confirmed deaths, with a further 77 injured; the Disaster Management Center reported 123,217 people of 35,354 families in 16 districts as having been affected, with 5,650 individuals of 1,424 displaced families having been provided shelter at 65 emergency welfare centers.[61]

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The Columbus Day storm of 1962 is identified as an extratropical storm or cyclone based on the provided information. The storm originated as a tropical disturbance over the Northwest Pacific on September 28, but it underwent an extratropical transition on October 10, becoming an extratropical cyclone as it moved into colder waters and interacted with the jet stream. However, post-season analysis concluded that the system continued weakening as it continued northeastward, crossing the 180th meridian later that afternoon, before completing the transition that evening.
Time_with_Annotation: As the cyclone moved through Canada, another cyclone formed on its southern periphery, which absorbed the original cyclone by October 17.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Deaths: At least 46 fatalities were attributed to this storm,
Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Injuries went into the hundreds.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Northwest and Northern California, Oregon and Washington
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: In terms of natural disaster-related fatalities for the 20th century, only Oregon's Heppner Flood of 1903 (247 deaths), Washington's Wellington avalanche of 1910 (96 deaths), the Great Fire of 1910 (87 deaths), and Eruption of Mount St. Helens of 1980 (57 deaths) caused more.

Total_Summary_Damage.Total_Damage: Approximately $230 million to $280 million for California, Oregon, and Washington combined.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Very Severe Cyclonic Storm Hikaa was a tropical cyclone that struck eastern Oman in September 2019.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: A deep-sea fishing boat with a crew of 11 capsized off of Masirah Island during the storm; there were five confirmed fatalities from the shipwreck, and one person was rescued.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Tanya was a tropical cyclone that transitioned into an extratropical storm as it passed through the Azores. The storm produced high winds that caused extensive property damage, including destroyed or damaged houses, sunken boats, and significant damage to agriculture. There was also one fatality and several injuries.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: In addition, there was one fatality and several injuries.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: One Spanish fisherman drowned and several people were injured.

Total_Summary_Damage.Total_Damage: Significant damage was reported in the Azores, particularly on the islands of Faial, Pico, Terceira and São Jorge. Extensive property damage was reported, including many capsized boats and several damaged or destroyed homes. Significant agricultural damage also occurred there. Many trees and power lines were knocked down, cutting electricity and hampering communications in the area. The highest wind gusts reported in the Azores were around 105 mph (170 km/h). After the storm, a resolution was submitted to the European Parliament by the Government of Portugal and a disaster area was declared in the islands.
Total_Summary_Damage.Total_Damage_Units: EUR or USD (No specific currency mentioned in the text)

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Cyclone Carmen was an extratropical cyclone and European windstorm which crossed the Atlantic Ocean and affected the United Kingdom, Ireland, France, Belgium, and the Netherlands in November 2010. Windstorm Carmen formed as a low-pressure system off the east coast of the United States and passed into the North Atlantic near and over southern Greenland, Iceland, and the Faroe Islands. Due to a strong pressure gradient, gale-force winds were recorded in the United Kingdom. The storm eventually attained a central pressure of 949 millibars as it struck the United Kingdom.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Two people died in southern Belgium, according to Dutch and RTBF. A man was washed away in a street and a 72-year-old woman was killed in her car. Both fatalities occurred during the night of the 13 November, in the community of Solre-Saint-Géry, part of Beaumont, near the French border.[24][25] Two more bodies were found in nearby Lessines.[26] In Cornwall, a motorist was killed by a falling tree in Yorkshire.[17] Another woman died in Pinderfield's Hospital after being impaled by a tree branch during winds of up to 90 mph in Pontefract, West Yorkshire.[17][18]

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Approximately 5,000 people were left without electricity in Northern Ireland.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Fiona was a large, powerful, and destructive Category 4 Atlantic hurricane which was the costliest and most intense tropical or post-tropical cyclone to hit Canada on record. It was the sixth named storm, third hurricane and first major hurricane of the 2022 Atlantic hurricane season. Fiona developed from a tropical wave that emerged from West Africa, before developing into a tropical depression east of the Leeward Islands on September 14. It strengthened into a hurricane as it approached Puerto Rico on September 18, and made landfall in the Dominican Republic shortly thereafter. Fiona then strengthened into the first major hurricane of the season and reached peak 1-minute sustained winds of 140 mph (220 km/h) and a minimum pressure of 931 mbar (27.49 inHg). After passing Bermuda and weakening to Category 3 intensity, Fiona quickly transitioned into a large and powerful extratropical cyclone and struck Nova Scotia with sustained winds of 100 mph (155 km/h) early on September 24.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Deaths: At least 29 deaths have been confirmed throughout the Caribbean and Canada from Hurricane Fiona as of September 30.
Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: At least 29 deaths have been confirmed throughout the Caribbean and Canada from Hurricane Fiona as of September 30.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: One person died when his house was washed away in the floods near the Rivière des Pères in the district of Basse-Terre.
At least 21 deaths in Puerto Rico have been attributed to the hurricane.
At least 2 people were killed in the Dominican Republic.

A Port aux Basques woman was killed when her home was destroyed and she was swept into the ocean; another person died of carbon monoxide poisoning while operating an electrical generator in Prince Edward Island.
Another man in Lower Prospect, Nova Scotia was swept out to sea and presumed dead.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Hurricane Fiona was the costliest and most intense tropical or post-tropical cyclone to hit Canada on record, causing >=$3.09 billion (2022 USD) in damages.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Man-yi was identified as a tropical storm and later reached peak intensity as a severe tropical storm before making landfall in Japan. (Paragraph: Man-yi still started intensifying and grew larger more later that day as it dropped a pressure of 20 millibars. Late on September 14, Man-yi became a severe tropical storm, absorbing few dry air and making a small unbalanced eye. Man-yi started moving towards Japan making more strong winds to Japan on September 15 and made landfall on September 16 near Toyohashi, Aichi Prefecture.)

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: Typhoon Man-yi made landfall in Toyohashi, Aichi Prefecture in 08:00am on September 15 as 2 people were reported dead and 6 missing. During the morning hours of September 16, another 4 people were dead by falling trees, landslides and flashfloods. Over 70 people were injured and at least one person was killed. The government of Japan set up emergency task forces and employed rescue teams. Many homes were flooded and about 80,000 were without electricity in western and central Japan. Trains in Tokyo and its vicinity were mostly suspended and hundreds of flights were grounded.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Two people were reported dead and 6 missing in Toyohashi, Aichi Prefecture on September 15. During the morning hours of September 16, another 4 people were dead by falling trees, landslides and flashfloods.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane San Roque was a destructive tropical cyclone in August 1893 that principally affected Puerto Rico, eastern New England, and Atlantic Canada. It was the third known hurricane of the 1893 Atlantic hurricane season. The system was first observed on August 13 at low latitudes east of the Lesser Antilles and grew to be a powerful, slow-moving hurricane in the Caribbean Sea. On August 17, it struck Puerto Rico at the equivalence of Category 3 on the modern-day Saffir–Simpson scale, causing widespread destruction, most notably along the northern coast. The storm then turned northeastward, accelerated, and gradually weakened, but still brought heavy rainfall and gale-force winds to the East Coast of the United States and Atlantic Canada.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Two more people died when their boat sank on Trinity Bay in Newfoundland, for a storm total of 37 fatalities.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Various locations, including Camuy, Isabela, Manatí, Bayamón, Trujillo Alto, Dorado, and San Juan
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: The storm caused four known fatalities in Puerto Rico.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The article mentions extensive damage to crops, telegraph infrastructure, and buildings in Puerto Rico, as well as damage to ships and boats throughout Atlantic Canada. However, it does not provide a specific amount for the total economic damage.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Severe Tropical Cyclone John was an intense tropical cyclone that rapidly deepened offshore before devastating areas of Western Australia. The system was the second cyclone and first severe tropical cyclone of the active 1999–00 Australian region cyclone season. Cyclone John developed from a monsoon trough positioned northwest of Australia on 9 December 1999. As it moved to the west and later south as the result of a subtropical ridge under favourable conditions, the cyclone was able to rapidly intensify. John reached peak intensity on 14 December as a Category 5 cyclone on the Australian cyclone scale, the highest rating possible.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The article states 'After the season, the name John was retired from the Australian tropical cyclone naming list. John was responsible for no deaths and a limited amount of damage.' (Paragraph 3)

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: 51 people were killed during the typhoon.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Pinamalayan in Oriental Mindoro was worst hit, with 15,000 homes destroyed, 24,000 families (108,000 people) in evacuation centers.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Nora, known in the Philippines as Typhoon Luming, was a tropical storm that formed on October 2, 1973, and reached typhoon status on October 3. It underwent a period of rapid intensification, during which its central pressure decreased by 77 mb (hPa; 2.27 inHg) in 24 hours, and peaked with winds of 295 km/h (185 mph) and a pressure of 875 mb (hPa; 25.91 inHg) on October 5. The typhoon subsequently weakened and made landfall in China on October 10.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: On 4 November 1966, an abnormal occurrence of high tides, rain-swollen rivers and a severe sirocco wind caused the canals to rise to a height of 194 cm or 6 ft 4 in. (paragraph 2) Thousands of residents were left without homes and over six million dollars worth of damage was caused to various works of art throughout Venice. (paragraph 3)

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Although Venice is known for its acque alte or high waters which often flood the streets, this flood left thousands of residents without homes and caused over six million dollars worth of damage to the various works of art throughout Venice. It was, up until 2022, the worst flood in the history of the city.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Although other Italian cities in Northern and Central Italy, such as Florence, Trento, and Siena, were all affected by the weather, Venice was the most severely affected. The city remained isolated for 24 hours, and having been unprepared for this type of emergency, more than 75 percent of businesses, shops, and artisans' studios, along with thousands of goods, were either seriously damaged or destroyed completely.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The flood left thousands of residents without homes and caused over six million dollars worth of damage to the various works of art throughout Venice. It was, up until 2022, the worst flood in the history of the city.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Dry conditions in September 2019 contributed to several small to mid-range fires in north eastern New South Wales. By November of that year, continuing heat and lack of rain had desiccated the forests and agricultural land along the Great Dividing range in New South Wales and Queensland. Sydney received less than 2 millimetres (0.079 in) of rain in December 2019, with temperatures reaching 40°C (104°F). Numerous intense bushfires occurred, some of which burnt Gondwanan rainforest remnants that had not experienced fires for millennia.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: From 7-10 February 2020, many areas on the east coast of New South Wales received heavy and continuous rain, the heaviest falls for thirty years. 391.6 millimetres (15.42 in) of rain fell over the four days in Sydney, more than three times the February average. Flooding was extensive, including areas such as Lake Conjola, that had been devastated by bushfires about 6 weeks earlier.
Queensland had experienced poor wet season rains for three consecutive seasons.
The state of New South Wales was declared to be 100% in drought by August 2018, remaining at 98.6% into May 2019.
Much of the region experiencing totals in the lowest 10% of historical observations, and was particularly low over the mainland southeast from April onwards.
Two southern parts of Western Australia were declared 'water deficient' by May 2019 after months of drought.

In eastern and northern Australia in the near future (to 2030), natural variability is anticipated to predominate over trends due to greenhouse gas emissions. However, even if climate change does not result in decreased rainfall in eastern and northern Australia over the period to 2030, the perceived severity of drought (in terms of low soil moisture) would increase on account of the higher evaporative demand resulting from the projected overall rise in average temperatures.

Total_Summary_Damage.Total_Damage: The article does not mention a specific total economic damage or loss caused by the southeast Australia bushfires.
Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The article does not provide any information on the total economic loss or damage caused by the southeast Australia bushfires.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Karen was a hurricane of non-tropical origin that formed in October of the 2001 Atlantic hurricane season. It developed out of the interaction between a cold front and an upper level trough, and quickly strengthened as an extratropical storm. The storm passed near Bermuda on October 12, producing hurricane-force winds on the island. It then organized, becoming a subtropical cyclone on October 12 and a tropical cyclone on October 13. Karen strengthened to reach 80 mph (130 km/h) winds as a Category 1 hurricane on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale, and after weakening over cooler waters, it made landfall on Nova Scotia as a tropical storm. It quickly became extratropical.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: "No fatalities were reported, though a few storm-related injuries occurred."

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Hurricane Karen caused moderate damage, totaling to about $1.4 million (2001 USD). In Bermuda, damage totaled to over $1.4 million (2001 USD; $1.7 million 2008 USD), primarily due to power line damage and damage to boats and houses. In Atlantic Canada, damage was minimal.
