Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The 2015 Northern Chile floods were a series of mudflows that affected much of northern Chile, product of flash floods from different rivers due to unseasonal heavy rains in the area.
Time_with_Annotation:
The 2015 Northern Chile floods were a series of mudflows that affected much of northern Chile, product of flash floods from different rivers due to unseasonal heavy rains in the area, causing severe damage in several towns of the Antofagasta, Atacama and Coquimbo regions.
Flooding in Chile and Peru resulted from an unusual cold front which moved across the Andes, bringing heavy rainfall to the region.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: "26 people died during the mudflow and 101 are officially missing, although it is expected that these numbers will increase as contact is reestablished with remote communities."[6]

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: "26 people died during the mudflow and 101 are officially missing, although it is expected that these numbers will increase as contact is reestablished with remote communities."[6]

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The February 9–11, 2017 North American blizzard was a fast-moving but powerful nor'easter that affected the Northeastern United States and Atlantic Canada with heavy snow and blizzard conditions. The system initially formed as an Alberta clipper in the northern United States and produced light snowfall in the Plains and Midwest. It later reached the East Coast and rapidly intensified into a nor'easter, producing up to 18 inches (46 cm) of snow and blizzard conditions in some areas before moving away on February 10.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: The February 9–11, 2017 North American blizzard affected the Northeastern United States, Mid-Atlantic states, especially the New England states, and Atlantic Canada.

In Atlantic Canada, accumulations of snow were reported between 10 and 30 centimetres (4 and 12 in) on February 9 and 10th with the maximum axis along Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island and Western Newfoundland.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: On March 21, an area of low pressure moved ashore on the West Coast, with a limited amount of moisture available. As it moved eastward on March 22, it started to intensify and snowfall began to become widespread. The storm also began to transition into an extratropical cyclone, achieving a peak of 989 millibars (29.2 inHg) two times on March 23. Blizzard warnings were issued for areas around Denver due to the strong winds accompanying the system along with snowfall. Parts of Interstate 80 were shut down due to the extreme winter weather conditions. Denver International Airport was also shut down.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: "Total fatalities: 117 total"

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: "Total fatalities: 117 total"

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Nestor was a large but short-lived and disorganized tropical storm which caused widespread tornadoes and heavy rain in the Southeastern United States during mid-October 2019. It gained a sufficient enough of a circulation to be designated Tropical Storm Nestor near the Florida Panhandle early on October 18.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: 3 indirect deaths occurred when heavy rains generated by Nestor's extratropical remnant caused a car crash in South Carolina.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: 3 indirect deaths occurred when heavy rains generated by Nestor's extratropical remnant caused a car crash in South Carolina.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Severe Tropical Cyclone Raja was a tropical cyclone that developed in the South Pacific in late December 1986. The system was first noted as a weak tropical disturbance and later developed into a tropical cyclone on 23 December. It interacted with another tropical cyclone, Sally, and executed a tight loop, passing within 55 km (35 mi) of Futuna. Raja peaked as a Category 3 severe tropical cyclone on 28 December, with estimated 10-minute sustained winds of 90 mph (150 km/h). The storm threatened Fiji, where it passed within 20 km (10 mi) of Vanua Levu and near (or over) several smaller islands in the Lau group during the following day. Raja gradually weakened over the next few days as it moved south of Fiji and was last noted on 5 January 1987.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Raja caused one death as it impacted the island nations of Tuvalu, Wallis and Futuna, Tonga and Fiji.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: One person drowned on the island of Lakeba as he and two others tried to move a boat to a safer anchorage.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Raja caused $14 million (1987 USD) in damage in the affected regions.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Nabi was a powerful tropical storm that struck southwestern Japan in September 2005. It formed as a tropical depression on August 29, east of Guam, and quickly organized as it moved westward. The storm intensified into a typhoon on August 31, reaching peak winds of 260 km/h (160 mph) on September 1. Nabi passed near Saipan on August 31 and made landfall in Japan on September 6, causing significant damage and leaving over 270,000 residences without power.

Time_with_Annotation.Formation: On August 28, a large area of convection persisted about 1,035 km (643 mi) east of Guam. Located within an area of moderate wind shear, the system quickly organized while moving westward, its track influenced by a ridge to the north. At 00:00 UTC on August 29, a tropical depression formed from the system, classified by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) as Tropical Depression 14W.
Time_with_Annotation.Peak_Intensity: On September 1, the JTWC upgraded the storm to a super typhoon and later estimated peak one-minute winds of 260 km/h (160 mph); this is the equivalent of a Category 5 on the Saffir–Simpson scale. By contrast, the JMA estimated peak ten-minute winds of 175 km/h (109 mph) on September 2, with a barometric pressure of 925 mbar (27.3 inHg).
Time_with_Annotation.Landfall: At 18:00 UTC on September 6, the JTWC discontinued advisories on Nabi, declaring it extratropical, although the JMA continued tracking the storm. On the next day, Nabi moved across northern Hokkaido into the Sea of Okhotsk. The JMA declared the storm as extratropical on September 8, which continued eastward until the JMA ceased monitoring the storm's remnants on September 10, while situated south of the Aleutian Islands.
Time_with_Annotation.Dissipation: The remnants of Nabi weakened and later moved into southwestern Alaska on September 12, dissipating soon afterward.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: "Overall, Nabi killed 35 people."

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: "In Japan, Nabi caused damage in 31 of the 47 prefectures, leaving over 270,000 residences without power. Torrential rains caused flooding and landslides throughout the country. The storm destroyed 7,452 houses and flooded 21,160 others. Several car assembly plants were damaged in southwestern Japan, while others were closed due to power outages. In addition, the storm wrecked about 81 ships along the coast. On the island of Kyushu, damage in Ōita Prefecture on Kyushu reached ¥11.7 billion (US$106 million), the fifth highest of any typhoon in the preceding 10 years; about 20% of the total there was related to road damages. In nearby Saga Prefecture, crop damage totaled about ¥1.06 billion (US$9.6 million), mostly to rice but also to soybeans and various other vegetables. Crop damage as a whole on Kyushu totaled ¥4.08 billion (US$36.9 million). In the capital city of Tokyo, heavy rainfall increased levels along several rivers, which inundated several houses. Strong winds damaged ¥28.8 million (US$259,000) in crop damage in Gifu Prefecture, and ¥27.1 million (US$244,000) in crop damage in Osaka. In Yamaguchi Prefecture on western Honshu, Nabi damaged a portion of the historical Kintai Bridge, originally built in 1674. In Yamagata Prefecture, the winds damaged a window in a school, injuring several boys from the debris. One person was seriously injured in Kitakata, Fukushima after strong winds blew a worker from scaffolding of a building under construction. Effects from Nabi spread as far north as Hokkaido, where heavy rainfall damaged roads and caused hundreds of schools to close. In Ashoro, an overflown river flooded a hotel, and a minor power outage occurred in Teshikaga. Ahead of the storm, high waves and gusty winds led to one drowning when a woman was knocked off a ferry in Takamatsu, Kagawa. A landslide in Miyazaki destroyed five homes, killing three people. A man who was listed as missing was found dead in a flooded rice field. In Tarumi, a landslide buried a home in mud, killing two people. Nabi caused a portion of the San’yō Expressway to collapse in Yamaguchi Prefecture, killing three people. In Fukui Prefecture, the winds knocked an elderly man off a bicycle, killing him. Overall, Nabi killed 29 people in Japan and injured 179 others, 45 of them severely."

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Irma originated from an active monsoon trough to the east of the Philippines and was first classified as a tropical storm on November 19. It attained typhoon intensity on November 21 with winds of up to 200 km/h (125 mph). Irma made landfall in the Philippines on November 24 with winds of 160 km/h (100 mph). The storm rapidly deteriorated overland but was still believed to have been a typhoon when it emerged into the South China Sea. Irma then began to re-curve towards the northwest while weakening and was estimated to have obtained extratropical characteristics on November 26.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: After striking the Philippines, the storm caused widespread damage while becoming the strongest storm to affect the archipelago since 1970. The hardest hit was the province of Camarines Norte along the eastern portion of the island of Luzon. A 15 m (50 ft) tidal wave swamped the towns of Garchitorena, Serona, Lagonoy and Caramoan in the Camarines Sur province, resulting in the deaths of 137 people. Virtually every house was demolished due to storm surge in Benagaspasan, a small town with a population 1,000, where 47 people were killed. Across much of Luzon, Irma flattened houses and flooding streets, resulting in considerable damage. Irma brought down power lines, which led to blackouts along the suburbs of Manila. Many other deaths occurred when they were crushed to death under collapsed houses or killed by flying debris. For instance, two people died when their house on Mindoro Island collapsed and a farmer in Quezon died after being hit by a falling coconut. Elsewhere on Midoro Island, 60 homes were destroyed. Offshore, eighteen fisherman were listed as missing. Twenty-six of the casualties happened in Manila while 12 others died in the rural town of Daet along the southern part of Luzon due to flooding and falling debris. Due to the storm, iron sheets were littered across the slums of Manila. Communication lines between Daet and Manila were disconnected; many villages between the two locations were destroyed. In Lucena, two people were killed and many coconuts were tossed from trees. In Bulacan, civil defense officials advised thousands of inhabitants on the banks of the Angat River to flee as water along the river threatened to overflow their banks. In the Rizal province, one agency reported that it dispatched several army trucks to fetch roughly 2,000 stranded 12- to 15-year-old boy scouts. In a nearby park, the typhoon blew down houses, power poles, billboards and trees. Even though the Clark Air Base and Subic Bay, both United States-run, sustained little damage, six C-130 transports had to be evacuated to the Kadena Air Base in Okinawa and ships, including the aircraft carrier Constellation.

Officials issued a tropical storm warning for Guam when Irma formed on November 17. Winds of 56 km/h (35 mph) were measured in addition to 81 km/h (50 mph) gusts. However, no major damage was reported.
The decaying remnants of Irma then brought 105 to 150 mm (5 to 5 in) of rain and winds of up to 72 km/h (45 mph) to Okinawa.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: A total of 595 were killed due to Irma.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: In Benagaspasan, a small town with a population 1,000, 47 killed.
In Caramoan, only one of 2,000 homes remained standing; 38 persons were killed.
In Garchitorena, a town with 20,000 residents, 117 people perished.
The communities of Serona and Lagonoy also suffered heavy damage.
Twelve others died in the rural town of Daet along the southern part of Luzon due to flooding and falling debris.
Twenty-six of the casualties happened in Manila.
Sixty homes were destroyed on Midoro Island.
A farmer in Quezon died after being hit by a falling coconut.
Two people were killed in Lucena.
Civil defense officials advised thousands of inhabitants on the banks of the Angat River to flee as water along the river threatened to overflow their banks.
One agency reported that it dispatched several army trucks to fetch roughly 2,000 stranded 12- to 15-year-old boy scouts.
The typhoon blew down houses, power poles, billboards and trees in a nearby park.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Clark Air Base and Subic Bay
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Despite the storm, both the Clark Air Base and Subic Bay, both United States-run, sustained little damage.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Overall, damage totaled to $63.3 million (1981 USD).[7]

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Hermine was a near-hurricane strength tropical cyclone that brought widespread flooding from Guatemala northwards to Oklahoma in early September 2010. Hermine developed directly from the remnant low-pressure area associated with the short-lived Tropical Depression Eleven-E in the East Pacific. The storm caused 52 direct deaths and roughly US$740 million in damage to crops and infrastructure, primarily in Guatemala.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: "52 direct, 50 indirect, 100 presumed dead"

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: "At least 41 people died along the highway and more than 100 others are believed to be dead"
"One of these killed four more people after destroying their home in Quetzaltenango"
"Heavy rains in Costa Rica associated with the system triggered a landslide that killed three people and displaced hundreds"
"At least 46 people are known to have been killed throughout Oaxaca"
"No loss of life or injuries took place in Matamoros"
"In Texas, eight fatalities, seven in Texas and one in Oklahoma, occurred"
"One person was killed after he drove his car into a flooded street and was swept away in Johnson County"
"90 people had to be evacuated from an apartment building after a nearby creek flooded, leaving some of the rooms under 8 ft (2.4 m) of water in Arlington"
"One fatality took place in Bell County after a 19-year-old girl drowned when her car was swept off a flooded road"
"Nearly all of Sequoyah County was left underwater, resulting in severe infrastructural damage. Preliminary estimates placed damage in the county were $2.5 million"

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The storm caused 52 direct deaths and roughly US$740 million in damage to crops and infrastructure, primarily in Guatemala.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Cary, known as Typhoon Ising in the Philippines, was a tropical storm that affected several countries including the Philippines, Hainan, Hong Kong, and Vietnam. The storm developed on August 6, 1987, and attained tropical storm intensity on August 14. It peaked in intensity on August 17 with winds of 160 km/h (100 mph) and made landfall in eastern Luzon, Philippines, while at peak intensity. The storm weakened over land but re-intensified into a typhoon over the South China Sea. It passed close to Hainan Island and made landfall in northern Vietnam on August 21. Across the Philippines, 954 houses were damaged and an additional 89 were destroyed, leaving 55,567 people homeless or seeking shelter. Five people died in the country and damage totaled $5.58 million (1987 USD). In Vietnam, almost 40,000 ha (98,840 acres) of land were flooded or destroyed, resulting in 20 fatalities and many injuries.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: "Twenty people were killed in the country" (Paragraph under 'Preparations and impact' section for Vietnam)

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: "Five people were killed in the country" (Paragraph under 'Preparations and impact' section for Philippines)

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Thanh Hoa, Ha Nam Ninh, Thai Binh and Haiphong
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: "Twenty people were killed in the country" (Paragraph under 'Preparations and impact' section for Vietnam)

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The storm inflicted $5.58 million in damage to the country, including $1.45 million from agriculture and $4.13 million from infrastructure.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Intense Tropical Cyclone Idai was one of the worst tropical cyclones on record to affect Africa and the Southern Hemisphere. The long-lived storm caused catastrophic damage and a humanitarian crisis in Mozambique, Zimbabwe, and Malawi, leaving more than 1,500 people dead and many more missing. Idai is the deadliest tropical cyclone recorded in the South-West Indian Ocean basin. In the Southern Hemisphere, which includes the Australian, South Pacific, and South Atlantic basins, Idai ranks as the second-deadliest tropical cyclone on record. The only system with a higher death toll is the 1973 Flores cyclone that killed 1,650 off the coast of Indonesia.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: At least 1,593 people were killed by Cyclone Idai and its aftermath.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: At least 532 people were killed in Beira, Mozambique, by Cyclone Idai.
People in Nhamatanda were swept to their deaths by a tsunami-like wave of water.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Num_Death: 100,000 people were reported as requiring rescue
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Thousands of people remained trapped on rooftops four days after Idai made landfall in Búzi.
At least 634 lives were lost in Chimanimani and Chipinge Districts, Malawi.
One person was killed in Besalampy, Madagascar, due to flooding and mudslides caused by Cyclone Idai.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Cyclone Apollo was a powerful Mediterranean tropical-like cyclone that affected many countries on the Mediterranean coast, especially Italy, in 2021. The storm killed 7 people total, due to flooding from the cyclone, in the countries of Tunisia, Algeria, Malta, and Italy, where the worst of the effects have been felt, especially on the island of Sicily. Damage estimates by the Aon Benfield were set at more than $245 million.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: The worst of the effects have been felt, especially on the island of Sicily.
Heavy rain from the cyclone and its precursor caused heavy rainfall and flooding, killing people.
The storm killed people in the countries of Tunisia, Algeria, Malta, and Italy.
Damage estimates by the Aon Benfield were set at more than $245 million, affecting many countries on the Mediterranean coast, including Malta.
Cyclone Apollo affected many countries on the Mediterranean coast, including Libya.
On 2 November 2021, Apollo dissipated inland over Turkey.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Heavy rain from the cyclone and its precursor caused heavy rainfall and flooding in Tunisia, Algeria, Southern Italy, and Malta, killing 7 people total.[1][5][14][15] The flooding was especially severe in the provinces of Catania and Siracusa, in Eastern Sicily.[3][4]

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Sicily, especially the provinces of Catania and Siracusa
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: The flooding was especially severe in the provinces of Catania and Siracusa, in Eastern Sicily.[3][4]

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Damage estimates by the Aon Benfield were set at more than $245 million.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation:
The 2006–2007 Southeast Asian floods were a series of floods that mostly affected Malaysia from 18 December 2006 to 13 January 2007. The floods were caused by above average rainfall, which was attributed to Typhoon Utor (2006) which had hit the Philippines and Vietnam a few days earlier.
Typhoon Utor was blamed for heavy rains of up to 350 mm within 24 hours in southern Peninsular Malaysia, specifically Johor, Negeri Sembilan, Malacca and Pahang, causing massive floods within the southern region on 18 December 2006.
The flooding began when torrential downpours caused rivers and dams to overflow.
The worst-affected areas were Segamat and Kota Tinggi, where both towns were totally inaccessible via land transport routes after all main roads leading to those towns were flooded.
At least 118 people died and 155 people were missing as of 29 December 2006.
Singapore and certain parts of Indonesia were also flooded due to the same typhoon.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Deaths: At least 118 people died and 155 people were missing as of 29 December 2006.
Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: An estimated 400,000 people were displaced at the peak of the flooding in Indonesia, with at least 118 people dead and 155 people missing as of 29 December 2006.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: An estimated 400,000 people were displaced at the peak of the flooding with at least 118 people dead and 155 people missing as of 29 December 2006.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The areas worst affected by the second flood were Batu Pahat and Kluang. Both waves of the flood disaster were considered as the costliest flood in Malaysian history, with the total cost of damage caused by the floods standing at RM 1.5 billion.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Neoguri (pronounced [nʌ.ɡu.ɾi]) was a large and powerful tropical cyclone which struck Japan in 2014. It developed into a tropical storm on July 3 and then a typhoon on July 4. Neoguri rapidly deepened on July 5, reaching peak intensity late on July 6. After Neoguri passed through the southern coast of Honshū on July 10, it became extratropical on July 11.

Time_with_Annotation.Landfall: Right before 07:00 JST on July 10 (22:00 UTC on July 9)

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: Throughout Japan, 3 deaths and 67 injures caused by Typhoon Neoguri were confirmed, according to the Fire and Disaster Management Agency of the Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications of the Government of Japan.
In Okinawa Prefecture, 580,000 people in 18 municipalities were advised to evacuate. Fourteen of these municipalities recommended evacuation for the entire area encompassed by the municipality.
A landslide sent mud and rock tumbling down a mountainside, killing a 12-year-old boy.
Neoguri made landfall near Akune, Kagoshima.
Rail service from Akayu Station was suspended due to rail line damage.
56 homes were inundated and evacuation orders were put in place for Shirataka.
Temperatures peaked at 38 °C (100 °F) in Tatebayashi while Tokyo recorded 34.2 °C (93.6 °F); measurements reached 31 °C (88 °F) in central Hokkaido.
Damage on the Jeju Island were at ₩223 million (US$220,000).
Parks and schools were closed.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: In Japan, 3 deaths and 67 injures caused by Typhoon Neoguri were confirmed, according to the Fire and Disaster Management Agency of the Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications of the Government of Japan.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: An 83-year-old man fell into a swollen river and died.
A landslide sent mud and rock tumbling down a mountainside, killing a 12-year-old boy.
A 77-year-old man was found dead in a canal.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Total damage in Japan topped at ¥64 billion (US$632 million).

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation:
On 8 August 2022, large scale floods hit the capital of South Korea, Seoul, especially Gangnam District and surrounding areas. It was preceded by the highest rainfall in 80 years.
2,800 buildings were damaged and at least 9 people were killed.
The highest recorded rainfall was 17 inches (43cm) in Seoul's Dongjak district.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: At least 9 people were killed.[2]

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: At least 9 people were killed.[2]

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Billie was the first tropical cyclone monitored by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. The storm brought severe flooding to several East Asian countries, including the Philippines, Japan, Taiwan, China, and South Korea. Billie developed from a tropical disturbance on July 12 and reached tropical storm intensity the next day before strengthening further to typhoon status on July 13. The typhoon reached its peak intensity on July 14 with maximum sustained winds of 165 km/h (103 mph) and a minimum barometric pressure of 970 hPa (mbar; 28.64 inHg). The rainbands of Billie brought destructive flooding to the affected areas, causing significant damage and fatalities.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: "Fatalities: 51 direct, 68 indirect"

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: "In the Philippines, one person was killed,"
"Floods were particularly destructive in Japan, where they destroyed 603 homes in the western portion of the country and killed 44 people."
"In total, the effects of Billie in Taiwan killed seven people. Extensive flooding also occurred in nearby eastern China, inundating rice fields and killing seven people."

"Storms accompanying Billie and its remnants brought heavy rains and strong winds to South Korea, knocking out police telephone lines in Busan. The sudden onslaught of these storms caused a stampede of roughly 70,000 people out of a stadium, resulting in the indirect deaths of 68 people, including 51 children. Around 125 people were injured and 40 were hospitalized after the mass evacuation."

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Flooding from Billie was highly destructive in areas of Japan west of the Chūbu region, destroying 603 homes and inundating 77,288 others. Roughly 325 km2 (125 sq mi) of farmland was impacted by the rains. Across Japan, 44 people were killed and 77 were injured.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Etau was a tropical storm that formed on August 8, 2009, and reached its peak intensity on August 10, 2009, with winds of 75 km/h (45 mph) and a barometric pressure of 992 hPa (mbar). Although it did not make landfall, the outer bands of the storm produced torrential rainfall in Japan, triggering deadly flooding and mudslides, especially in Hyōgo Prefecture. Twenty-eight people were killed by the storm and ¥7.1 billion (US$87.5 million) in damage occurred throughout the affected region.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Twenty-eight people were killed by the storm and ¥7.1 billion (US$87.5 million) in damage occurred throughout the affected region.[1][2]

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: In Hyōgo Prefecture where hundreds of homes were flooded and numerous others were damaged or destroyed by landslides.[1] Three bridges in Tokushima were also washed away.[31] Following severe damages, in the town of Sayo it requested assistance from the national government. As a result, more than 200 troops were deployed to the town.[23][24] The Japanese Fire and Disaster Management Agency finalized the death toll at 26 with one other missing,[1][2] making Etau the deadliest tropical cyclone to impact Hyōgo Prefecture, Japan since Typhoon Tokage in 2004.[32]

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Morakot, known in the Philippines as Typhoon Kiko, was the deadliest typhoon to impact Taiwan in recorded history. The storm originated as a tropical depression in the West Pacific on August 2 and developed into a tropical storm on August 3. Morakot intensified into a severe tropical storm and later a typhoon on August 5. The storm reached its peak intensity on August 7, with a minimum central pressure of 945 millibars (27.9 inHg), maximum 10-minute sustained winds of 140 km/h (85 mph), and maximum 1-minute sustained winds of 150 km/h (90 mph). Morakot made landfall in central Taiwan later that day as a severe tropical storm and later made landfall in Mainland China on August 9.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: According to statistics of the Morakot Post-Disaster Reconstruction Council up to February 4, 2010, the disaster resulted in 677 deaths, 4 severely injured, and 22 missing persons, as well as an additional 25 bodies that were not identified: a total of 728 persons (cases).

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Siaolin Village, a mountain village with 1,300 residents in Jiasian Township, was buried by a massive landslide (and subsequent flood) that destroyed the town, and  resulted in 465 deaths.
On August 14, Xiaolin Village was completely covered due to a landslide, causing the deaths of 398 people.
Three French tourists and two Filipino guides were killed in a flash flood caused by a landslide.

A landslide in Pengxi, at the foot of a mountain, destroyed a three-story apartment building, with six people inside. All six were recovered from the rubble of the structure. However, two later died of their injuries.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Talim was a tropical storm that formed on September 8, 2017, and became a typhoon on September 10, 2017. It passed over Japan on September 17, 2017, before transitioning to an extratropical storm on September 18, 2017. The storm caused 5 fatalities and over $750 million worth of damages in Japan.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: 5 deaths were reported and over 73 were injured, all in Japan.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Various locations, including Miyazaki and Kumamoto
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: An 86-year-old woman was found dead on September 17, due to her house pounded by a landslide in Kagawa Prefecture, while on Kōchi Prefecture, a 60-year man drowned in his car, due to a swollen river, and two bodies were recovered from a riverbank. In Oita Prefecture, a 70-year man was recorded missing, before founding him in an unknown place. The last fatality of the storm was reported at Hokkaido, when another man, possibly in his 80s, was found dead in a beach.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Judy was upgraded into a tropical storm on September 6 and a typhoon on September 8. It intensified into a typhoon with winds of 150 km/h (90 mph) and a pressure of 950 mbar (28 inHg) on September 9.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: "Across Japan, a total of 26 people were killed, eight others were rendered as missing, and 86 were injured." (Paragraph 2)

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: "Across Japan, a total of 26 people were killed, eight others were rendered as missing, and 86 were injured." (Paragraph 2)

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Michael was a powerful and destructive tropical cyclone that made landfall in the contiguous United States as a Category 5 hurricane, the first such storm to do so since Andrew in 1992. It was the third-most intense Atlantic hurricane to make landfall in the contiguous United States in terms of pressure, behind the 1935 Labor Day hurricane and Hurricane Camille in 1969. Michael was the first Category 5 hurricane on record to impact the Florida Panhandle, causing catastrophic damage in the areas around Mexico Beach and Tyndall Air Force Base.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: At least 15 fatalities occurred: eight in Honduras, four in Nicaragua, and three in El Salvador. In Honduras, torrential rain caused at least seven rivers to overtop their banks; nine communities became isolated. More than 1,000 homes sustained damage, of which 9 were destroyed, affecting more than 15,000 people. Nationwide, 78 shelters housed displaced persons and relief agencies procured 36 tonnes of aid.

About 70% of the offshore Isla de la Juventud lost power. On the southern coast of the island, La Coloma was inundated by storm surge, sinking ships and flooding homes. High winds left more than 200,000 people without power in the province of Pinar del Río, accounting for 90% of the province. Officials sent 500 power workers to the area to restore electricity. Widespread damage was inflicted on tobacco crops, leading to the complete loss of 18,000 seedbeds of tobacco in the province; the hurricane struck Cuba coincident with the start of the sowing season for tobacco on October 10. More than 600 hectares (1,500 acres) of rice were also damaged by Michael's rainfall. At least 694 homes in Cuba were damaged by the hurricane, including 300 in Sandino.

According to the Edison Electric Institute, at one point 1.2 million electricity customers were without power in several east coast and southern states. Estimated damage from Michael throughout the United States reached $25 billion. The most severe impacts occurred along the Florida coast between Panama City Beach and Cape San Blas, with catastrophic impacts in the areas around Mexico Beach and Tyndall Air Force Base. Impacts were evident on all types of buildings, though structures built before 2002 fared substantially worse. Damage to over 2.8 million acres (1.1 million hectares) of forested land caused an estimated $1.29 billion in damage to the timber industry; 12% of damaged forest area was classified as 'catastrophic' by the Florida Forest Service. Around 28% of global longleaf pine ecosystems were affected by the hurricane in Florida; near the storm's center, tree mortality was as high as 87.8%. Damage to various agricultural sectors, chiefly cotton, cattle, and peanuts, amounted to $180 million. Seven deaths were directly caused by the hurricane's forces, including five drownings due to storm surge and two deaths due to fallen trees; the drownings all involved elderly individuals. There were another 43 deaths indirectly caused by Michael, including those that occurred during the storm's aftermath and those from health complications exacerbated by the hurricane, resulting in 50 deaths total in Florida attributed to Michael.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Deaths: At least 50 deaths were attributed to Hurricane Michael, including 43 indirect deaths and 7 direct deaths.
Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Five hundred deaths total in Florida were attributed to Michael, including those that occurred during the storm's aftermath and those from health complications exacerbated by the hurricane.

At least 15 fatalities occurred in Central America: eight in Honduras, 4 in Nicaragua, and 3 in El Salvador.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Severe Tropical Cyclone Debbie in 2017 was the strongest tropical cyclone to strike Queensland since Marcia in 2015, and was the costliest tropical cyclone in Australia since Yasi in 2011. Debbie formed as a tropical low on 23 March and intensified into a named tropical cyclone on 25 March. After steadily strengthening offshore, Debbie made landfall near Airlie Beach on 28 March. The storm caused significant damage and flooding in the populous areas of South East Queensland and Northern Rivers, resulting in fourteen deaths and A$3.5 billion (US$2.67 billion) in damage.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation:
An total of eight deaths were reported throughout Queensland.
Two more people were confirmed to have drowned in floodwaters on 1 April, another south of Murwillumbah and one at Gungal.
A woman drowned in floodwaters at a rural property south of Murwillumbah, while the Pacific Motorway was cut off by floodwaters at Chinderah.
A man in Proserpine also suffered an injury and was hospitalised after a wall collapsed on him on 28 March.
Inclement weather and evacuations associated with the cyclone were blamed for a fatal car accident near Proserpine on 27 March, where one person died on-scene whilst two others were hospitalised.
A total of six people in New South Wales died due to the cyclone.
A week after becoming extratropical, the remnants of Cyclone Debbie passed over New Zealand, causing flash flooding over many areas. Two people drowned in floodwaters in New Zealand.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Cyclone Steve was a tropical cyclone that affected northern Australia from 27 February 2000 until 11 March 2000. The system rapidly intensified to become a tropical cyclone at around 7 am AEST on 27 February 2000 and made four distinct landfalls in the country.

Time_with_Annotation.Formation: Tropical Cyclone Steve was formed on 27 February 2000.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: As Steve tracked inland on the north Queensland coast, it caused major flooding between Cairns and Mareeba. A record flood level of 12.4 m (41 ft) was reached at Mareeba on 28 February 2000. Many buildings in Cairns suffered severe water damage including the Cairns Hospital. Cairns recorded its wettest February on record with the suburb of Manunda measuring 1,462.7 mm (57.59 in) and Bartle Frere recording 3,376 mm (132.9 in). Wind gusts up to 140 km/h (87 mph) caused several buildings in Cairns and Kuranda to lose their roofs. Hundreds of trees were uprooted and powerlines were brought down throughout the district, disrupting supplies to more than 40,000 residents. In Cairns, a giant fig tree was uprooted with the entire root system out of the ground. Crop damage by floods and winds was severe, with the sugar cane damage alone estimated at A$20 million. Early estimates indicate that the total damage bill in north Queensland associated with Cyclone Steve may exceed A$100 million.

Severe winds squalls and heavy rainfall was recorded across the Top End. Several trees were uprooted in Gunbalanya (Oenpelli) which reported winds gusts in excess of 90 km/h (56 mph). Gusts near 90 km/h (56 mph) in Darwin overnight on 2 March brought down trees. Widespread flooding resulted in the Katherine, Daly and Victoria River regions. Water levels in the Katherine River came to within about 3 metres (9.8 feet) of those experienced in the 1998 floods but subsided without inundating the town. Rainfall across the Top End, Victoria River region over a four-day period between 29 February to 4 March was between 200 and 400 millimetres (7.9 and 15.7 inches). Numerous Northern Territory roads and highways were cut with many communities isolated.

Near gale-force winds were experienced at Port Hedland for a period of about 17 hours beginning at midnight AWST on 5 March. The peak hourly average wind speed recorded was 72 km/h (45 mph) and the maximum gust recorded was 104 km/h (65 mph) (between 8 and 9 am AWST 6 March). Winds averaged near 70 km/h (43 mph) at Karratha in the early evening 6 March and the maximum gust recorded was 98 km/h (61 mph) at 6 pm AWST. The very heavy rainfall associated with Steve produced widespread flooding in northern parts of the state, including the Gascoyne region. Communities in the Kimberley region which remained isolated for more than two weeks required food and supply air-drops. Low-lying areas of the Carnarvon townsite were flooded when the Gascoyne River breached its banks. The Gascoyne River at Carnarvon reached its highest level since 1960.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The article does not mention any fatalities directly related to Tropical Cyclone Steve.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Laura was a deadly and destructive Category 4 hurricane that made landfall in the U.S. state of Louisiana, as measured by maximum sustained winds.

Tropical Storm Vicente was an unusually small tropical cyclone that made landfall as a tropical depression in the Mexican state of Michoacán on October 23, 2018. The storm caused deadly mudslides and heavy rainfall in multiple states, including Oaxaca and Veracruz.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation:
Vicente made landfall near Playa Azul, Michoacán, at 13:30 UTC (08:30 CDT) on October 23.
Schools along the coast of Michoacán were closed to safeguard everyone from the effects of Vicente and Willa.
Rainfall from the storm flooded 27 neighborhoods in the city of Morelia.
Vicente damaged schools, health care facilities, houses, and crops in the Sierra Mazateca area.
Emergency declarations were issued for 167 municipalities that were severely affected.
The Mexican Army and Navy alongside State Police deployed 10,000 personnel to assist in recovery efforts.
Plan DN-III-E was activated to disperse aid to the state; a Mexican Air Force helicopter was utilized to get food and supplies to people in affected areas.
A disaster declaration was issued for 71 Oaxacan municipalities affected by Vicente; these areas would have access to national disaster relief funds.
Several communities were inundated in Hidalgotitlán after the Coatzacoalcos river overflowed; 790 homes were flooded in the towns of Ramos Millán and Vicente Guerrero.
Shelters were set up for affected families and 500 pantries distributed water.
Classes in the area were canceled as a result of the floods.
Twenty-one emergency declarations were authorized for municipalities in the state.

The system brought heavy rainfall to Oaxaca, causing widespread flooding and mudslides.
Torrential rainfall filled four Oaxacan dams to their highest levels in over four years; two of the dams exceeded 90% of their capacity and another exceeded 100%. 
The floods left 21 communities without any outside communication.
Roads in Oaxaca suffered severe damage in 203 sections; machinery was apportioned to clear landslides off roads.
At least 13 people died throughout the state, 6 of whom died in a landslide in San Pedro Ocotepec.
A family of four went missing after trying to leave one of the communities.
A landslide in Santiago Camotlán buried a house and killed a 40-year-old man.
In Tututepec, a 56-year-old man drowned after getting caught in river currents.
Multiple rivers in the state overtopped their banks and inundated nearby communities.
A landslide in Santiago Choapam destroyed three homes.
A drainage ditch emptying into the Chahué Bay overflowed, flooding at least 80 homes and businesses; a portion of the ditch also collapsed.
Rainfall caused a sinkhole to develop on a bridge.
A total of five cars were swept away by water currents flowing down streets in Santa Cruz Huatulco.
As a result of the flooding, a temporary shelter was enabled in that area.
National Commission for the Development of Indigenous Peoples facilities were activated to help 30 people who were affected.
The ports of Puerto Ángel, Puerto Escondido, and Huatulco were closed.
Several communities in the Sierra Norte region were isolated and left without any outside communication by landslides and damaged bridges.
Crops in that area were destroyed by the storm, leading to food shortages.

Rainfall from the storm triggered flooding in Veracruz, leaving three people dead.
A declaration of emergency was issued for 13 municipalities in Veracruz.
The World Heritage city of Tlacotalpan prepared for the overflow of the Papaloapan river by creating levees to prevent floodwaters from affecting historical and cultural sites.
Multiple landslides were reported on the Zomgolia-Orizaba highway.
In the southern portion of the state, the Veracruz-Coatzacoalcos highway was blocked by floodwaters after the Tesochoacán river overflowed.
Throughout the state, 21 landslides occurred, and 42 roads and 36 schools sustained damage.
In the municipality of Álamo-Temapache, the Oro Verde stream and the Pantepec river overflowed, flooding multiple streets.
Plan DN-III-E was enabled to aid with relief in the state.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: "The heavy rainfall caused numerous rivers to spill their banks, dozens of landslides to occur, and severe flooding to ensue elsewhere. This resulted in hundreds of homes being inundated, dozens of road closures, and agricultural damage amongst an array of other effects. Plan DN-III-E was activated in multiple states to provide aid to affected individuals. The federal and state governments mobilized to help with relief efforts and repairs. In total, 16 people were killed throughout 2 states: 13 in Oaxaca and 3 in Veracruz."

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: "At least 13 people died throughout the state (Oaxaca), 6 of whom died in a landslide in San Pedro Ocotepec. A family of four went missing after trying to leave one of the communities. Rescue searches for the individuals ceased a week later; they were assumed to have been buried by a landslide. A landslide in Santiago Camotlán buried a house and killed a 40-year-old man. In Tututepec, a 56-year-old man drowned after getting caught in river currents."
"Rainfall from the storm triggered flooding in Veracruz, leaving three people dead."

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Felicia was a powerful tropical storm that formed in the eastern Pacific Ocean in August 2009. It quickly intensified into a hurricane, reaching peak winds of 145 mph (233 km/h) and a minimum central pressure of 935 mbar (hPa; 27.61 inHg). The storm weakened as it approached Hawaii, but its remnants still caused significant rainfall and flooding on several islands. In Oahu, the heaviest rainfall was recorded at 14.63 in (372 mm), causing mudslides, flooding, and isolating some residents. The storm also helped alleviate drought conditions on Maui and significantly increased the total water across the island's reservoirs.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The article states that 'Fatalities: None'.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: After weakening into a remnant low, Felicia continued to approach the Hawaiian Islands and on August 12, the system produced copious amounts of rainfall across several islands. In all, only minor impacts were caused by the remnants of Felicia.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Cyclone Imogen was a tropical cyclone that affected parts of northern Queensland. The system caused approximately $10 million in damages.
Time_with_Annotation: Imogen later accelerated North-East before finally dissipating on January 6.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Fatalities: None reported

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Imogen caused at least $10 million of damages.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: The main event is a series of three European windstorms named Ylenia, Zeynep, and Antonia (or Dudley, Eunice, and Franklin) that impacted the United Kingdom and continental Europe between February 16th and 21st, 2022. These windstorms were driven by a strong jet stream and occurred within a short space of time, making it difficult to precisely allocate insurance claims to a specific storm given their similar impacts on affected areas.

Time_with_Annotation.Ylenia: impacted the United Kingdom and continental Europe between February 16th and 17th, 2022.
Time_with_Annotation.Zeynep: impacted Ireland and the United Kingdom first, before crossing into other parts of Western and Central Europe on February 18th and 19th, 2022.
Time_with_Annotation.Antonia: struck the UK late Sunday and parts of Europe into Monday, February 20th and 21st, 2022.
Time_with_Annotation.Dudley: impacted the UK and then crossed Western and Central Europe on February 16th and 17th, 2022.
Time_with_Annotation.Eunice: impacted Ireland and the United Kingdom first, before crossing into other parts of Western and Central Europe on February 18th and 19th, 2022.
Time_with_Annotation.Franklin: struck the UK late Sunday and parts of Europe into Monday, February 20th and 21st, 2022.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The article does not provide any information on the total number of deaths associated with Ylenia, Zeynep, Antonia, Dudley, Eunice, or Franklin.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation:
The insurance and reinsurance industry loss from the three major European windstorms that struck close together during the month of February 2022 has been lifted to EUR 3.61 billion by data aggregator PERILS AG.
These European windstorms impacted the United Kingdom and continental Europe between February 16th and 21st.
It’s no surprise the second loss estimate is higher than the first, as other sources of loss estimate data had originally pegged them higher than PERILS.
PERILS estimate remains towards the lower-end of expectations, given it had been thought the industry loss from these three storms may rise as high as EUR 5 billion by Fitch Ratings, while RMS had said Eunice alone could be as high as EUR 3.5 billion and when combined with Dudley losses could reach EUR 4.5 billion, and Verisk pegged just Dudley and Eunice at between EUR 3 to EUR 5 billion.
However, as we noted at the time of the first estimate, PERILS estimate will always undercount the actual insurance and reinsurance industry impact across the entire region, given the company does not collect loss data in certain countries.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Nida was a tropical storm that reached typhoon status with winds of 115 mph (185 km/h). It later became a super typhoon with winds of 165 mph (266 km/h) and a defined eye measuring 25 miles (40 km) wide. The storm made landfall in the Philippines and caused severe structural damage, displacing 11,000 people and leaving 31 fatalities. Nida produced heavy rainfall across the eastern Philippines, causing flooding and landslides. In Japan, heavy rains produced by the outer bands of Nida triggered flash flooding and landslides. The storm weakened and transitioned to an extratropical cyclone by May 21.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: "31 fatalities (20 confirmed, 11 unaccounted for) were reported during Nida's landfall."

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Location_Death: Various locations, including Camotes island, Nueva Ecija, and offshore
Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: "31 fatalities (20 confirmed, 11 unaccounted for) were reported during Nida's landfall. In Camotes island, nine people drowned and five were declared missing when a ferry boat sank during the storm. Elsewhere offshore, 13 crewmen were rescued when their ship ran aground near Luzon."

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Between 1 and 3 April 2013, the northeastern section of Buenos Aires Province, Argentina, experienced several flash floods that claimed the lives of 101 people. The flooding was the result of extremely heavy rainfall and is said to be the worst flooding in La Plata's history.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: Based on the provided article, the 2013 Argentina floods affected the northeastern section of Buenos Aires Province, Argentina.
Greater Buenos Aires and Greater La Plata in Buenos Aires Province were specifically mentioned as being hardest hit by the floods.

"Three days of national mourning were declared on 3 April. Two days later, government benefits for flood victims were announced."

"In Greater La Plata, an estimated 3,000 people were evacuated, many after waiting hours for rescue in trees and on roof tops of flooded homes. Half of the city lost power and vast portions were underwater."

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Severe Tropical Cyclone Yasa was the second tropical cyclone and severe tropical cyclone of the 2020–21 South Pacific cyclone season. It was first noted as an area of low pressure and gradually developed further as it absorbed Tropical Depression 01F. The system was classified as a tropical cyclone and named Yasa on December 13. Yasa maintained its intensity and became more defined on satellite imagery as it bore down on Fiji. The storm caused significant damage in Fiji, with estimates reaching FJ$500 million (US$246.7 million).

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Four deaths were confirmed, while one person remains missing.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Four deaths were confirmed, while one person remains missing.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: European windstorms Mike-Niklas struck Europe at the end of March, causing significant damage across Western and Central Europe. The two storms occurred close together and affected the area within a 36 hour period, making it difficult to allocate losses to the individual storms. Niklas was by far the stronger storm and likely responsible for the bulk of the losses.

impacting much of Western and Central Europe

Losses also occurred in Austria.
Niklas, also known as Lentestorm in the Netherlands,

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The fourth and final insurance industry loss estimate for European windstorms Mike & Niklas has been released this morning by PERILS AG and it sees the total reduced again to €816m, now 4% lower than the initial loss estimate.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Fanapi, known in the Philippines as Typhoon Inday, was a damaging and deadly typhoon that struck Taiwan and southeastern China in September 2010. It was the eleventh tropical storm and fourth typhoon of the very inactive season. The storm formed on September 14 east of the Philippines and moved slowly for several days, initially to the northwest, then curving to the northeast before turning westward due to a ridge to the north. During this time, Fanapi intensified to reach 10 minute maximum sustained winds of 175 km/h (109 mph). Fanapi made its first landfall on September 19 over Hualien, Taiwan, becoming the first typhoon to hit the island since Typhoon Morakot in August 2009. Later that day made a final landfall in Fujian, China. The storm dissipated on September 21 over southern China.

Time_with_Annotation.Formation: An area of convection, or thunderstorms, persisted west of Guam on September 13, in association with the monsoon trough. The system gradually developed a low-level circulation and rainbands, aided by low wind shear from an anticyclone aloft. Late on September 14, the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) designated the system as a tropical depression to the east of the Philippine island of Luzon. Around the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) classified the system as Tropical Depression 12W.
Time_with_Annotation.Landfall_in_Taiwan: Early on September 19, Typhoon Fanapi made landfall over eastern Taiwan near Hualien City with winds of 162 km/h (101 mph), according to Taiwan's Central Weather Bureau. The storm subsequently weakened over land, dipping southwestward as convection diminished over the northern portion of the storm. However, the storm resumed its westward trajectory and soon moved over the Taiwan Strait as a severe tropical storm.
Time_with_Annotation.Landfall_in_China: Fanapi made a second landfall on southeastern China near Fujian and weakened further over land, although thunderstorms persisted southeast of the circulation along the coast. Fanapi weakened into a tropical depression later that day and dissipated late on September 21.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: There were five deaths in Taiwan during the storm's passage, and damage was estimated at NT$5 billion (US$158 million). In southeastern China, 100 people were killed, including 28 in Xinyi due to a collapse at a mine.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: There were five deaths in Taiwan during the storm's passage.
In Xinyi, a storm-related landslide collapsed a dam at a mine, killing 28 people.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Fernand was a short-lived tropical storm that caused severe flooding in northern Mexico in early September 2019. Fernand developed from a broad area of low pressure that was first monitored in the southeastern Gulf of Mexico on August 31. The cyclone quickly strengthened into Tropical Storm Fernand six hours after formation, and attained peak winds of 50 mph (80 km/h) early on September 4.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: In the municipality of García, a Venezuelan man died after he was swept away by floodwaters while trying to clean a sewer; two others who were with him at the time were rescued.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: A Venezuelan man died after he was swept away by floodwaters while trying to clean a sewer; two others who were with him at the time were rescued.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Initial damage in Nuevo León was estimated to be MX$7.5 billion (US$383 million). Two months later, the National Civil Protection found that the damage in Nuevo León was just MX$222 million (US$11.3 million).

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation:
The January 2012 Pacific Northwest snowstorm was a large extratropical cyclone that brought record snowfall to the Pacific Northwest in January 2012.

---

The storm was first noted just off the coast of British Columbia on January 16, with a central pressure of 1,018 millibars (30.1 inHg).

---

The storm then began to move closer to the coastline, and by 2000 UTC on January 18, the storm was located about 40 miles (64 km) off the coast of Washington.

---

The National Weather Service (NWS) began issuing severe weather warnings for the whole of the Pacific Northwest on January 17 and 18. A hurricane-force wind warning was issued for offshore Oregon at about 1600 UTC on January 18. A storm warning was also issued for parts of California and Oregon.

---

Numerous flights were cancelled due to heavy snow and rain.

---

Interstate 5 near Centralia, Washington, was closed temporarily due to powerlines brought down by snowfall; the standard detour route was also blocked by trees and powerlines.

---

Amtrak service between Portland and Seattle was canceled due to trees and debris left on tracks.

---

More than 12 Oregon highways were closed due to storm damage, and many more were partly closed.

---

Oregon Route 213 near Molalla closed for several days due to an undermined roadbed beside a culvert.
Time_with_Annotation: First noted just off the coast of British Columbia on January 16, with a central pressure of 1,018 millibars (30.1 inHg).
The center of the low pressure area had then moved south to about 300 miles (480 km) off the Oregon Coast. At the same time, the storm had attained peak intensity of 992 millibars (29.3 inHg).
By 2000 UTC on January 18, the storm was located about 40 miles (64 km) off the coast of Washington.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: A mother and child were killed in Oregon after the car they were in slid into a creek,[4][5] while a man was killed in the Seattle area.[6]

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: A mother and child were killed in Oregon after the car they were in slid into a creek,[4][5] while a man was killed in the Seattle area.[6]

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Across Europe and parts of Asia, unusually high-temperatures in the late-winter period were reported from February 20 until February 28, 2021. The onset of the short-lasting winter heat wave was caused by a jet stream of Saharan dust. Daily high temperatures for the period were similar to the maximum high temperatures during spring.
Time_with_Annotation: From February 20 until February 28, 2021

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: The article does not provide information on the total economic loss or damage caused by the 2021 Eurasia winter heat wave.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Utor, known in the Philippines as Super Typhoon Labuyo, was a powerful, deadly and destructive tropical cyclone that struck the Philippines and southern China. Utor started originating near Yap, tracking westwards in a favorable development, allowing the system to be better organized. All agencies have upgraded the system as a depression, with JTWC designated as Tropical Depression 11W and PAGASA naming the depression as Labuyo. Developing into a tropical storm on August 9, Utor soon underwent explosive intensification and became a Category 4 super typhoon within a half day.

Time_with_Annotation.Start: Early on August 8, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) reported that a tropical disturbance had developed north of Yap.
Time_with_Annotation.End: The remnants later dissipated on August 18.

A total of 86 people were killed in Mainland China, while total damages were amounted to be ¥21.5 billion (US$3.51 billion).

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Severe Tropical Cyclone Ita was the strongest tropical cyclone in the Australian region by central pressure since George in 2007, and by wind speed since Monica in 2006. The system was first identified over the Solomon Islands as a tropical low on 1 April 2014, and gradually moved westward, eventually reaching cyclone intensity on 5 April. On 10 April, Ita intensified rapidly into a powerful Category 5 system on the Australian Scale, but it weakened to a Category 4 system in the hours immediately preceding landfall the following day.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Approximately 40 total fatalities

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Throughout the Solomon Islands, 22 people were killed
Unconfirmed reports of casualties were received from the hardest hit areas in Milne Bay Province
On Ware Island, 54 homes and 1 classroom were destroyed, resulting in 54 fatalities

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: A massive storm complex developed at the end of 2012, producing both a tornado outbreak and a blizzard across the southern and eastern United States. On Christmas Day 2012, a tornado outbreak occurred across the Southern United States, affecting the Gulf Coast and southern East Coast over a two-day span. The tornadoes were caused by a vigorous upper-level trough that moved southeast into Texas from the Rocky Mountains, forming a powerful, negatively-tilted shortwave trough. This provided enough energy for the formation of discrete tornadic supercells ahead of the advancing squall line in Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: Near the end of 2012, a massive storm complex developed that produced both a tornado outbreak and a blizzard across the southern and eastern United States.
Environment Canada also reported that the system began impacting Ontario that day, bringing heavy snow to the province.

That same day, Environment Canada reported heavy and blowing snow over Montreal, Quebec. The system moved into the Northeast early December 28, with the upper-level trough moving just off the coast of the Delmarva Peninsula. The system reached its lowest reported central pressure of 987 mb (29.15 inHg) at this point.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Deaths: At least 16 people died as a result of the related blizzard.
Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: During the next couple of days, the system slowly moved into the Atlantic Ocean, before accelerating eastward across the Atlantic on December 30. On December 31, the winter storm was absorbed by another extratropical cyclone, just northwest of the United Kingdom. That same day, Environment Canada reported heavy and blowing snow over Montreal, Quebec. Early on December 28, the system moved through Nova Scotia, bringing heavy rain and snow before it moved out over the Atlantic Ocean. (...) At least 16 people died as a result of the related blizzard, and thousands were without power.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Two people were killed in separate weather-related car crashes in Virginia. (...) Two people were killed in separate weather-related automobile accidents in Virginia. (...) Two people were killed in a traffic accident in Indiana caused by snowy roads. (...) Two people were killed in a highway accident as a result of sleet on the roads in Arkansas. (...) One person was killed when high winds knocked over a tree onto a house. (...) The driver of a truck was killed in Texas when strong winds knocked over a tree, which fell on the vehicle. (...) At least 16 people died as a result of the related blizzard.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Damage: >$150 million

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Cyclone Alan developed into a tropical cyclone on April 21, 1998, and reached its estimated peak intensity with 10-minute maximum sustained wind speeds of 75 km/h (45 mph) on April 22. The system posed several forecasting challenges due to difficulties in establishing its location and intensity.

Country_with_Annotation.Annotation: The system passed near to or over the French Polynesian Society Islands of Maupiti, Bora-Bora, and Ra'iātea, causing several landslides, the collapse of two bridges, and obstruction of roads by fallen trees. Damage was mainly confined to the Leeward Islands of Bora Bora, Tahaa, Ra'iātea and Huahine.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: On the islands, around 10 people died as a result of the system, while thirty others were injured.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Ten people died as a result of the system.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Cyclone Xaver (or Storm Xaver), also known as the North Sea flood or tidal surge of 2013, was a winter storm that affected northern Europe. The storm formed off the west coast of Iceland and was expected to deepen explosively, leading to warnings of a significant risk of storm surge and coastal flooding along the coasts of the North and Irish Seas.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Five people were killed in Poland, including three people in a car when a tree struck it in Poraj, northern Poland. The storm also caused two deaths in the UK and one in Denmark. In Sweden a total of seven people died.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Five people were killed in Poland, including three people in a car when a tree struck it in Poraj, northern Poland.

The storm brought gusts up to 229 km/h (142 mph) to upland Scotland. Lower lands in the UK and mainland Europe saw some damaging gusts. One point on the Danish-German border peaking at 158 km/h (98 mph). Poland saw maximum gusts averaging about 137 km/h (85 mph). Two people died in the UK.
One person died in Denmark.
In Sweden, a total of seven people died.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Tropical Storm Josephine was an unusual Atlantic tropical storm that moved from west to east across the Gulf of Mexico in October 1996. It formed on October 4 as a tropical depression and intensified into a tropical storm on October 6, reaching peak winds of 70 mph (110 km/h) on October 7. The storm made landfall in Taylor County, Florida, on October 8, and soon after became extratropical.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Damage throughout the United States totaled about $130 million (1996 USD). Josephine later moved offshore, and after passing southeast of Cape Cod, moved through Atlantic Canada with moderate rainfall and gusty winds. The storm later restrengthened in the northern Atlantic Ocean before merging with another extratropical storm near Iceland on October 16. In the southeastern United States, the storm contributed to dozens of traffic accidents, which killed a person each in Georgia, North Carolina, and Virginia.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: In the southeastern United States, the storm contributed to dozens of traffic accidents, which killed a person each in Georgia, North Carolina, and Virginia.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Frank was a Tropical Storm/Cyclone that caused minor damage in Mexico in late August 2010.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: A total of six people were killed with over 800,000 people affected.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: A total of six deaths were reported.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: In the aftermath of the storm, damage repairs from Hurricane Frank totaled to 100 million pesos (US$8.3 million).

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Cleo was the strongest tropical cyclone of the 1964 Atlantic hurricane season. It was a hurricane that travelled through the Caribbean Sea and later hit Florida before moving offshore Georgia into the Carolinas, killing 156 people and causing roughly $187 million in damages. (...) Hurricane Cleo was a tropical storm/cyclone.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: Major damage was seen as far north as east-central Florida, with the heaviest rains falling along the immediate coast of the Southeast United States into southeast Virginia. Cleo killed 156 people and caused roughly $187 million in damages.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Official reports from Guadeloupe indicated 14 dead, 40 injured, 1,000 homes destroyed and extensive damage to the island's infrastructure. The hurricane devastated sugar and banana plantations.
Les Cayes, Haiti was leveled as the storm struck the town.

Cleo intensified rapidly just prior to landfall, bringing sustained winds of 100–105 mph (161–169 km/h) with gusts to 135 mph (217 km/h) to the Miami area. Major damage was constrained to a 20–35 miles (32–56 km) wide strip from Miami to Melbourne, in the form of broken glass, interior flooding, uprooted trees, overturned aircraft, power failures, and agriculture. Cleo cut power to 620,000 homes and businesses in southeast Florida. At least two dozen fires blazed across Miami. About a quarter of the grapefruit crop was lost within the Indian River citrus producing region. The storm surge reached 4–6 feet (1.2–1.8 m) between Miami and Pompano Beach. The highest rainfall total measured within Florida was 9.37 inches (238 mm) at Stuart.

Heavy rains spread up along the Georgia coast into the Carolinas and southern Virginia in association with the weakening tropical storm. Interaction with a frontal boundary to its north led to significant rains across extreme southeast Virginia to the left of its track exceeding 14 inches (360 mm) in the Norfolk metropolitan area. Seven tornadoes were reported within South Carolina, while North Carolina witnessed three tornado touchdowns.

Total_Summary_Damage.Economic_Impact_with_annotation: Major damage was seen as far north as east-central Florida, with the heaviest rains falling along the immediate coast of the Southeast United States into southeast Virginia.

Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Hurricane Ike was a powerful tropical cyclone that caused devastation from the Louisiana coastline all the way to the Kenedy County region near Corpus Christi, Texas. The storm made landfall on the northeast end of Galveston Island in Texas, with sustained winds of 110 mph (180 km/h), making Ike a Category 2 hurricane.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Deaths: At least 214 people died as a result of Hurricane Ike.
Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation:
Two additional deaths were reported in the Dominican Republic.
Seven people were killed in Cuba due to drowning or collapsing structures.
113 direct and indirect deaths have been reported in the US, including 85 in Texas (18 direct), eight in Louisiana, one in Arkansas, two in Tennessee, one in Kentucky, seven in Indiana, four in Missouri, two in Illinois, two in Michigan, seven in Ohio and one in Pennsylvania.
As of August 2011, 16 people remain unaccounted for, 11 of them in the Galveston area.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: Seven people were killed in Cuba from Ike due to drowning or collapsing structures.
113 direct and indirect deaths have been reported in the US, including 85 in Texas (18 direct).
74 deaths were reported in Haiti from Ike, most of which were in the coastal community of Cabaret which was swept away by floodwaters and mudslides.

It strengthened into a tropical storm on August 16 and later became a Category 1 hurricane on August 21. Henri made landfall in Westerly, Rhode Island, on August 22, and rapidly weakened into a tropical depression the next day.
